subject: Make RabbitMQ OCF script tolerate rabbitmqctl timeouts
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-27 14:33:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/87173dd679ca9cf821cb3109b101b613aa8dcccd', 'message': "Make RabbitMQ OCF script tolerate rabbitmqctl timeouts

The change makes OCF script ignore small number of timeouts of rabbitmqctl
for 'heavy' operations: list_channels, get_alarms and list_queues.
Number of tolerated timeouts in a row is configured through new variable
'max_rabbitmqctl_timeouts'. By default, it is set to 5.

Bug #1487517 is fixed by extracting declaration of local variables
'rc_alarms' and 'rc_queues' from assignment operations.

DocImpact: Ops Guide. If on node where RabbitMQ is deployed
other processes consume significant part of CPU, RabbitMQ starts
responding slow to queries by 'rabbitmqctl' utility. The utility is
used by RabbitMQ's OCF script to monitor state of the RabbitMQ.
When utility fails to return in pre-defined timeout, OCF script
considers RabbitMQ to be down and restarts it, which might lead to
a limited (several minutes) OpenStack downtime. Such restarts
are undesirable as they cause downtime without benefit. To
mitigate the issue, the OCF script might be told to tolerate
certain amount of rabbitmqctl timeouts in a row using the following
command:
  crm_resource --resource p_rabbitmq-server --set-parameter \
      max_rabbitmqctl_timeouts --parameter-value N

Here N should be replaced with the number of timeouts. For instance,
if it is set to 3, the OCF script will tolerate two rabbitmqctl
timeouts in a row, but fail if the third one occurs.

By default the parameter is set to 1, i.e. rabbitmqctl timeout is not
tolerated at all. The downside of increasing the parameter is that
if a real issue occurs which causes rabbitmqctl timeout, OCF script
will detect that only after N monitor runs and so the restart, which
might fix the issue, will be delayed.

To understand that RabbitMQ's restart was caused by rabbitmqctl timeout
you should examine lrmd.log of the corresponding controller on Fuel
master node in /var/log/docker-logs/remote/ directory. Here lines like
"the invoked command exited 137: /usr/sbin/rabbitmqctl list_channels ..."

indicate rabbitmqctl timeout. The next line will explain if it
caused restart or not. For example:
"rabbitmqctl timed out 2 of max. 3 time(s) in a row. Doing nothing for now."

Closes-Bug: #1479815
Closes-Bug: #1487517
Change-Id: I9dec06fc08dbeefbc67249b9e9633c8aab5e09ca

Text for documentation, Ops Guide:

If on node where RabbitMQ is deployed
other processes consume significant part of CPU, RabbitMQ starts
responding slow to queries by 'rabbitmqctl' utility. The utility is
used by RabbitMQ's OCF script to monitor state of the RabbitMQ.
When utility fails to return in pre-defined timeout, OCF script
considers RabbitMQ to be down and restarts it, which might lead to
a limited (several minutes) OpenStack downtime. Such restarts
are undesirable as they cause downtime without benefit. To
mitigate the issue, the OCF script might be told to tolerate
certain amount of rabbitmqctl timeouts in a row using the following
command:
  crm_resource --resource p_rabbitmq-server --set-parameter \
      max_rabbitmqctl_timeouts --parameter-value N

Here N should be replaced with the number of timeouts. For instance,
if it is set to 3, the OCF script will tolerate two rabbitmqctl
timeouts in a row, but fail if the third one occurs.

By default the parameter is set to 1, i.e. rabbitmqctl timeout is not
tolerated at all. The downside of increasing the parameter is that
if a real issue occurs which causes rabbitmqctl timeout, OCF script
will detect that only after N monitor runs and so the restart, which
might fix the issue, will be delayed.

To understand that RabbitMQ's restart was caused by rabbitmqctl timeout
you should examine lrmd.log of the corresponding controller on Fuel
master node in /var/log/docker-logs/remote/ directory. Here lines like
"the invoked command exited 137: /usr/sbin/rabbitmqctl list_channels ..."

indicate rabbitmqctl timeout. The next line will explain if it
caused restart or not. For example:
"rabbitmqctl timed out 2 of max. 3 time(s) in a row. Doing nothing for now."

DocImpact: user-guide, operations-guide

Closes-Bug: #1479815
Closes-Bug: #1487517

Bug #1487517 is fixed by extracting declaration of local variables
'rc_alarms' and 'rc_queues' from assignment operations.

commit_message:
Make RabbitMQ OCF script tolerate rabbitmqctl timeouts

The change makes OCF script ignore small number of timeouts of rabbitmqctl
for 'heavy' operations: list_channels, get_alarms and list_queues.
Number of tolerated timeouts in a row is configured through a new variable
'max_rabbitmqctl_timeouts'. By default it is set to 1, i.e. rabbitmqctl
timeouts are not tolerated at all.

Bug #1487517 is fixed by extracting declaration of local variables
'rc_alarms' and 'rc_queues' from assignment operations.


Text for Operations Guide:

If on node where RabbitMQ is deployed
other processes consume significant part of CPU, RabbitMQ starts
responding slow to queries by 'rabbitmqctl' utility. The utility is
used by RabbitMQ's OCF script to monitor state of the RabbitMQ.
When utility fails to return in pre-defined timeout, OCF script
considers RabbitMQ to be down and restarts it, which might lead to
a limited (several minutes) OpenStack downtime. Such restarts
are undesirable as they cause downtime without benefit. To
mitigate the issue, the OCF script might be told to tolerate
certain amount of rabbitmqctl timeouts in a row using the following
command:
  crm_resource --resource p_rabbitmq-server --set-parameter \
      max_rabbitmqctl_timeouts --parameter-value N

Here N should be replaced with the number of timeouts. For instance,
if it is set to 3, the OCF script will tolerate two rabbitmqctl
timeouts in a row, but fail if the third one occurs.

By default the parameter is set to 1, i.e. rabbitmqctl timeout is not
tolerated at all. The downside of increasing the parameter is that
if a real issue occurs which causes rabbitmqctl timeout, OCF script
will detect that only after N monitor runs and so the restart, which
might fix the issue, will be delayed.

To understand that RabbitMQ's restart was caused by rabbitmqctl timeout
you should examine lrmd.log of the corresponding controller on Fuel
master node in /var/log/docker-logs/remote/ directory. Here lines like
"the invoked command exited 137: /usr/sbin/rabbitmqctl list_channels ..."

indicate rabbitmqctl timeout. The next line will explain if it
caused restart or not. For example:
"rabbitmqctl timed out 2 of max. 3 time(s) in a row. Doing nothing for now."

DocImpact: user-guide, operations-guide

Closes-Bug: #1479815
Closes-Bug: #1487517
Change-Id: I9dec06fc08dbeefbc67249b9e9633c8aab5e09ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/38/217738/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OCF_RESKEY_max_rabbitmqctl_timeouts_default=5: ${OCF_RESKEY_max_rabbitmqctl_timeouts=${OCF_RESKEY_max_rabbitmqctl_timeouts_default}}# Verify if su_rabbit_cmd exited by timeout by checking its return code. # If it did not, return 0. If it did AND it is # $OCF_RESKEY_max_rabbitmqctl_timeouts'th timeout in a row, # return 2 to signal get_monitor that it should # exit with error. Otherwise return 1 to signal that there was a timeout, # but it should be ignored. Timeouts for different operations are tracked # separately. The second argument is used to distingush them. check_timeouts() { local op_rc=$1 local crm_attr_name=$2 if [ $op_rc -ne 124 -a $op_rc -ne 137 ]; then ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name $crm_attr_name --update 0 return 0 fi local count=`crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name $crm_attr_name --query 2>/dev/null | awk '{print $3}' | awk -F "=" '{print $2}' | sed -e '/(null)/d'` count=$((count+1)) # There is a slight chance that this piece of code will be executed twice simultaneously. # As a result, $crm_attr_name's value will be one less than it should be. But we don't need # precise calculation here. ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name $crm_attr_name --update $count if [ $count -lt $OCF_RESKEY_max_rabbitmqctl_timeouts ]; then ocf_log warn "${LH} rabbitmqctl times out for $count time(s) in a row. Doing nothing for now." return 1 else ocf_log err "${LH} rabbitmqctl times out for $count time(s) in a row. The resource is failed." return 2 fi } # Skip all other checks if rabbit app is not running if [ $rabbit_running -ne $OCF_SUCCESS ]; then ocf_log info "${LH} RabbitMQ is not running, get_monitor function ready to return ${rc}" return $rc fi local rc_alive local timeout_alive rc_alive=$? check_timeouts $rc_alive "rabbit_list_channels_timeouts" timeout_alive=$? if [ $timeout_alive -eq 2 ]; then elif [ $timeout_alive -eq 0 ]; then if [ $rc_alive -ne 0 ]; then ocf_log err "${LH} rabbitmqctl list_channels exited with errors." rc=$OCF_ERR_GENERIC fi local alarms local rc_alarms local timeout_alarms alarms=`su_rabbit_cmd "${OCF_RESKEY_ctl} -q eval 'rabbit_alarm:get_alarms().'"` rc_alarms=$? check_timeouts $rc_alarms "rabbit_get_alarms_timeouts" timeout_alarms=$? if [ $timeout_alarms -eq 2 ]; then return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC elif [ $timeout_alarms -eq 0 ]; then if [ $rc_alarms -ne 0 ]; then ocf_log err "${LH} rabbitmqctl get_alarms exited with errors." rc=$OCF_ERR_GENERIC elif [ -n "${alarms}" ]; then for node in "${alarms}"; do name=`echo ${node} | perl -n -e "m/memory,'(?<n>\S+)+'/ && print \"$+{n}\n\""` if [[ "${name}" == "${RABBITMQ_NODENAME}" ]] ; then ocf_log err "${LH} Found raised memory alarm. Erasing the alarm and restarting." su_rabbit_cmd "${OCF_RESKEY_ctl} set_vm_memory_high_watermark 10 2>&1 > /dev/null" rc=$OCF_ERR_GENERIC break fi done fi local queues local rc_queues local timeout_queues queues=`su_rabbit_cmd "${OCF_RESKEY_ctl} -q list_queues memory messages consumer_utilisation"` rc_queues=$? check_timeouts $? "rabbit_list_queues_timeouts" timeout_queues=$? if [ $timeout_queues -eq 2 ]; then return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC elif [ $timeout_queues -eq 0 ]; then if [ $rc_queues -ne 0 ]; then ocf_log err "${LH} rabbitmqctl list_queues exited with errors." elif [ -n "${queues}" ]; then local q_c=`echo -e "${queues}" | wc -l` local m_b=`echo -e "${queues}" | awk -v sum=0 '{sum+=$1} END {print sum}'` local mem=$(( $m_b / 1048576 )) local mes=`echo -e "${queues}" | awk -v sum=0 '{sum+=$2} END {print sum}'` local c_u=`echo -e "${queues}" | awk -v sum=0 -v cnt=${q_c} '{sum+=$3} END {print (sum+1)/(cnt+1)}'` local status=`echo $(su_rabbit_cmd "${OCF_RESKEY_ctl} -q status")` ocf_log info "${LH} RabbitMQ is running ${q_c} queues consuming ${mem}m of ${TOTALVMEM}m total, with ${mes} queued messages, average consumer utilization ${c_u}" ocf_log info "${LH} RabbitMQ status: ${status}" ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name 'rabbit_list_channels_timeouts' --update '0' ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name 'rabbit_get_alarms_timeouts' --update '0' ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name 'rabbit_list_queues_timeouts' --update '0'
deleted_lines: # The rabbit app may be not running and the command # will return > 0, so we only check if the command execution # has timed out (which is a code 137 or 124) local rc_alive=$? if [ $rc_alive -eq 137 -o $rc_alive -eq 124 ]; then ocf_log err "${LH} rabbitmqctl is not responding. The resource is failed." # Skip the check if rabbit app is not running yet. local alarms=`su_rabbit_cmd "${OCF_RESKEY_ctl} -q eval 'rabbit_alarm:get_alarms().'"` local rc_alarms=$? if [ $rc_alarms -eq 0 -a -n "${alarms}" ]; then for node in "${alarms}"; do name=`echo ${node} | perl -n -e "m/memory,'(?<n>\S+)+'/ && print \"$+{n}\n\""` if [[ "${name}" == "${RABBITMQ_NODENAME}" ]] ; then ocf_log err "${LH} Found raised memory alarm. Erasing the alarm and restarting." su_rabbit_cmd "${OCF_RESKEY_ctl} set_vm_memory_high_watermark 10 2>&1 > /dev/null" rc=$OCF_ERR_GENERIC break fi done # Skip the check if rabbit app is not running yet. local queues=`su_rabbit_cmd "${OCF_RESKEY_ctl} -q list_queues memory messages consumer_utilisation"` local rc_queues=$? if [ $rc_queues -eq 0 -a -n "${queues}" ]; then local q_c=`echo -e "${queues}" | wc -l` local m_b=`echo -e "${queues}" | awk -v sum=0 '{sum+=$1} END {print sum}'` local mem=$(( $m_b / 1048576 )) local mes=`echo -e "${queues}" | awk -v sum=0 '{sum+=$2} END {print sum}'` local c_u=`echo -e "${queues}" | awk -v sum=0 -v cnt=${q_c} '{sum+=$3} END {print (sum+1)/(cnt+1)}'` local status=`echo $(su_rabbit_cmd "${OCF_RESKEY_ctl} -q status")` ocf_log info "${LH} RabbitMQ is running ${q_c} queues consuming ${mem}m of ${TOTALVMEM}m total, with ${mes} queued messages, average consumer utilization ${c_u}" ocf_log info "${LH} RabbitMQ status: ${status}" fi # If the rabbit app is running, # we have to additionally check here if the channels/queues/alarms list results were ok. if [ $rabbit_running -eq $OCF_SUCCESS ]; then # Check if the rabbitmqctl control plane returned no errors for issued requests. if [ $rc_alive -ne 0 -o $rc_alarms -ne 0 -o $rc_queues -ne 0 ]; then ocf_log err "${LH} rabbitmqctl exited with errors."

commit_message:
Add PciNumaInfoWeigher

On some hosts numa node info is not reported for pci devices.
This weigher will allow Nova to prioritize hosts that properly
report numa node info during scheduling. If a VM doesn't request
PCI devices all host will have same weight.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint input-output-based-numa-scheduling

Change-Id: Ibaafc5bed8663273cb47d2dc1b3b96caf1b8e2aa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/152915/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import mockfrom nova.scheduler.weights import pci_numa_info class PciNumaInfoWeigherTestCase(test.NoDBTestCase): def setUp(self): super(PciNumaInfoWeigherTestCase, self).setUp() self.weight_handler = weights.HostWeightHandler() self.weighers = [pci_numa_info.PciNumaInfoWeigher()] def _get_weighed_host(self, hosts, multiplier, weighing_properties): if multiplier is not None: self.flags(pci_numa_info_weight_multiplier=multiplier) return self.weight_handler.get_weighed_objects( self.weighers, hosts, weighing_properties)[0] def _get_all_hosts(self): host_values = [ ('host1', 'node1', {'pci_stats': mock.Mock(return_value=1)}), ('host2', 'node2', {'pci_stats': mock.Mock( **{'support_requests.side_effect': (lambda x, y: x)})}), ] return [fakes.FakeHostState(host, node, values) for host, node, values in host_values] def _do_test(self, pci_numa_info_weight_multiplier, expected_weight, expected_host, weighing_properties): hostinfo_list = self._get_all_hosts() weighed_host = self._get_weighed_host(hostinfo_list, pci_numa_info_weight_multiplier, weighing_properties) self.assertEqual(weighed_host.weight, expected_weight) if expected_host: self.assertEqual(weighed_host.obj.host, expected_host) def test_pci_numa_info_weight_pci_requests_with_numa(self): weighing_properties = {'pci_requests': mock.Mock(requests=0)} self._do_test(pci_numa_info_weight_multiplier=1.0, expected_weight=1.0, expected_host='host2', weighing_properties=weighing_properties) def test_pci_numa_info_weight_pci_request_no_numa(self): weighing_properties = {'pci_requests': mock.Mock(requests=1)} self._do_test(pci_numa_info_weight_multiplier=1.0, expected_weight=0.0, expected_host='host1', weighing_properties=weighing_properties) def test_pci_numa_info_weight_no_pci_requests(self): # We do not know the host, all have same weight. self._do_test(pci_numa_info_weight_multiplier=1.0, expected_weight=0.0, expected_host='host1', weighing_properties={})

subject: rbd: use rbd snapshots and cloning for ephemeral disk snapshots
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-03 13:00:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/84b816a917973dedb0c7d6a4f10ac3d9622c0538', 'message': 'Implement proper snapshotting for ceph-based ephemeral disks

When using rbd as a storage backend for both glance images and nova
ephemeral disks, we can perform the snapshotting inside ceph itself
without copying the raw image locally and re-uploading it again.

This makes rbd based ephemeral disks much more usable.

Change-Id: Idefa95f126f2922acf008038e2ac7430b1d26a33
Implements: blueprint implement-rbd-snapshots-instead-of-qemu-snapshots
Closes-Bug: 1346525
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-10-03 14:29:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1e8e62e40a0d33269a00daf3fd78fae2a7a03b2e', 'message': 'Implement proper snapshotting for ceph-based ephemeral disks

When using rbd as a storage backend for both glance images and nova
ephemeral disks, we can perform the snapshotting inside ceph itself
without copying the raw image locally and re-uploading it again.

This makes rbd based ephemeral disks much more usable.

Change-Id: Idefa95f126f2922acf008038e2ac7430b1d26a33
Implements: blueprint implement-rbd-snapshots-instead-of-qemu-snapshots
Closes-Bug: 1346525
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-01-06 13:42:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/14bc57f80c2e0063cc95824570347d5bd9ce5c46', 'message': "rbd: use rbd snapshots and cloning for ephemeral disk snapshots

When rbd is used for ephemeral disks and image storage, we can avoid
local disk by doing the snapshot with ceph, and sending the location
of it to glance.

At this point glance is effectively the owner of the snapshot, and
nova cannot delete the original disk, so a corresponding change to
glance is needed to handle this cleanup later, when the snapshot is
deleted.

To accomplish this, create an rbd clone and store the clone's location
in glance, and when nova deletes an rbd disk with snapshots, rename
the disk to include a marker that glance looks for to know they can be
deleted when glance deletes the snapshots.

This requires changing the typical permissions for the glance ceph
user to allow writing to the pool where vm images are stored.

Change-Id: Idefa95f126f2922acf008038e2ac7430b1d26a33
Implements: blueprint implement-rbd-snapshots-instead-of-qemu-snapshots
Closes-Bug: 1346525

commit_message:
rbd: use rbd snapshots and cloning for ephemeral disk snapshots

When rbd is used for ephemeral disks and image storage, we can avoid
local disk by doing the snapshot with ceph, and sending the location
of it to glance.

At this point glance is effectively the owner of the snapshot, and
nova cannot delete the original disk, so a corresponding change to
glance is needed to handle this cleanup later, when the snapshot is
deleted.

To accomplish this, create an rbd clone and store the clone's location
in glance, and when nova deletes an rbd disk with snapshots, rename
the disk to include a marker that glance looks for to know they can be
deleted when glance deletes the snapshots.

This requires changing the typical permissions for the glance ceph
user to allow writing to the pool where vm images are stored.

DocImpact: glance will need write access to rbd to delete snapshots
Change-Id: Idefa95f126f2922acf008038e2ac7430b1d26a33
Implements: blueprint implement-rbd-snapshots-instead-of-qemu-snapshots
Closes-Bug: 1346525

added_lines: def create_snapshot(self, snap_name): self.driver.snapshot(self.pool, self.rbd_name, snap_name)

*) Add osprofiler wsgi middleware
This middleware is used for 2 things:
1) It checks that person who want to trace is trusted and knows
secret HMAC key.
2) It start tracing in case of proper trace headers
and add first wsgi trace point, with info about HTTP request

*) Add initialization of osprofiler at start of serivce
Set's olso.messaging notifer instance (to send notifications to Ceilometer)

commit_message:
Integrate OSprofiler and Nova

*) Add osprofiler wsgi middleware
This middleware is used for 2 things:
1) It checks that person who want to trace is trusted and knows
secret HMAC key.
2) It start tracing in case of proper trace headers
and add first wsgi trace point, with info about HTTP request

*) Add initialization of osprofiler at start of serivce
Set's olso.messaging notifer instance (to send notifications to Ceilometer)

*) Fix fake notifier

Based on: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/105096/

Co-Authored-By: Boris Pavlovic <boris@pavlovic.me>

Change-Id: I23b6e4f466c81bc8ebd1a85ceb3689fffa379674
Signed-off-by: Munoz, Obed N <obed.n.munoz@intel.com>

commit_message:
Network scheme 7.0: add public iface to br-ex in dvr mode

Proper transformation is not added to network scheme after recent
refactoring. This patch fixes the bug and adds corresponding test.

Closes-Bug: #1492138
Change-Id: I5d1336a10f855e17dede93d156cf586ca5f708f3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/42/220442/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_public_iface_added_to_br_ex_in_dvr(self): attrs = self.cluster.attributes.editable attrs['neutron_advanced_configuration']['neutron_dvr']['value'] = True resp = self.app.patch( reverse( 'ClusterAttributesHandler', kwargs={'cluster_id': self.cluster.id}), params=jsonutils.dumps({'editable': attrs}), headers=self.default_headers ) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status_code) self.assertTrue(objects.Cluster.neutron_dvr_enabled(self.cluster)) objects.Cluster.set_network_template(self.cluster, None) computes = filter(lambda n: 'compute' in n.roles, self.cluster.nodes) self.assertTrue(len(computes) > 0) compute = computes[0] serializer = get_serializer_for_cluster(self.cluster) net_serializer = serializer.get_net_provider_serializer(self.cluster) self.assertIs(net_serializer, NeutronNetworkDeploymentSerializer70) nm = objects.Cluster.get_network_manager(self.cluster) networks = nm.get_node_networks(compute) public_net = [net for net in networks if net['name'] == 'public'][0] self.assertIsNotNone(public_net) self.assertFalse(objects.Node.should_have_public_with_ip(compute)) network_scheme = net_serializer.generate_network_scheme( compute, networks) expected = {'action': 'add-port', 'bridge': 'br-ex', 'name': public_net['dev']} self.assertIn(expected, network_scheme['transformations'])

subject: Revert "turn multi host true for nova network by default"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-04 14:15:27.000000000', 'files': ['lib/nova'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/975243189216561f66ca91520495e0c6e2f747e2', 'message': 'Revert "turn multi host true for nova network by default"

This reverts commit 2e1a91c50b73ca7f46871d3a906ade93bbcac6a7

It looks like this introduced race bug 1491949 in the
gate-tempest-dsvm-large-ops job causing rpc timeouts when
deallocating network information for an instance,
specifically around the dnsmasq callback to release the
fixed IP that the instance was using which triggers the
disassociation between the fixed IP and the instance in the
nova database.

Change-Id: I163cdeea75e92485f241647c69aea0d7456c3258
Closes-Bug: #1491949
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "turn multi host true for nova network by default"

This reverts commit 2e1a91c50b73ca7f46871d3a906ade93bbcac6a7

It looks like this introduced race bug 1491949 in the
gate-tempest-dsvm-large-ops job causing rpc timeouts when
deallocating network information for an instance,
specifically around the dnsmasq callback to release the
fixed IP that the instance was using which triggers the
disassociation between the fixed IP and the instance in the
nova database.

Change-Id: I163cdeea75e92485f241647c69aea0d7456c3258
Closes-Bug: #1491949
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/25/220525/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MULTI_HOST=$(trueorfalse False MULTI_HOST)

commit_message:
Disable v3 API by default

Since v3 is still unstable and has experimental status it's
better to disable it by default for security reasons. This
commit does it by setting 'enable_v3_api=False'.

Also all required documentation was added to related sections.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I412d0645d667400333532123008a24966aa23880
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/09/215709/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: If the Glance API server parameter ``enable_v2_api`` or ``enable_v3_api`` has been set to ``True`` and the parameter ``data_api`` has been set to ``glance.db.registry.api`` the ``enable_v2_registry`` has to be set to ``True``The glance-api service implements versions 1, 2 and 3 of the OpenStack Images API. Disable either version of the Images API using the following options:* ``enable_v3_api=<True|False>`` Optional. Default: ``False`` glance-registry service while the v2 and v3 API are not. This means that in order to use the v2 and v3 API, you must copy the necessary sql configuration from your glance-registry service to your glance-api configuration file.
deleted_lines: If the Glance API server parameter ``enable_v2_api`` has been set to ``True`` and the parameter ``data_api`` has been set to ``glance.db.registry.api`` the ``enable_v2_registry`` has to be set to ``True``The glance-api service implements versions 1 and 2 of the OpenStack Images API. Disable either version of the Images API using the following options:glance-registry service while the v2 API is not. This means that in order to use the v2 API, you must copy the necessary sql configuration from your glance-registry service to your glance-api configuration file.

subject: Fix keystone client usage in barbican client
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-02 07:06:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum/commit/9444884c98a3b375294807fd84ebeec23ec5d87e', 'message': 'Fix keystone client usage in barbican client

In magnum.common.clients, barbican client uses `keystone()._client`
directly, but `keystone().client` is better. Because..

*   `keystone()._client` is None if it was not loaded.
*   `keystone().client` can return keystone client which has
    admin privilege.

This fixes it.

Change-Id: I3771ebef9c2a1d3756ea4ed2f964751d1c2da43f
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-09-02 07:17:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum/commit/233603e27521d95361fbb7773e2cab6684a76358', 'message': 'Fix keystone client usage in barbican client

directly, but `keystone().client` is better. Because..

*   `keystone()._client` is None if it was not loaded.
*   `keystone().client` can return keystone client which has
    admin privilege.

This fixes it.

commit_message:
Fix keystone client usage in barbican client

In magnum.common.clients, barbican client uses
`keystone()._client` directly, but `keystone().client`
is better. Because, keystone()._client is None is it
is not loaded.

This fixes it.

Closes-Bug: #1491257
Change-Id: I3771ebef9c2a1d3756ea4ed2f964751d1c2da43f

commit_message:
Allow to use autodetection of volume device path

API contract says, device is optional. We should allow the
device property to be nullable
http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html#attachVolume

Note that in python nova client "auto" is turned into None for the
device before the call is made to Nova API.

Closes-Bug: #1491325
Change-Id: Ibfd83b6abdfeec328019246a372363cada53869e

commit_message:
Introduce unit test for genconfig

We don't have unit test for genconfig, so sometimes this feature
is broken because of missing options or moving options.
This patch adds checking test for config parameters.

Change-Id: I67a44ef02704f66740a6bda2b6502b6b1636a08b
Closes-Bug: #1490825

added_lines: ===========This plugin test checks for the use of the Python `assert` keyword. It was discovered that some projects used assert to enforce interface constraints, however, assert is removed with compiling to optimised byte code (\*.pyo). This caused various protections to be removed. The use of assert is also considered as general bad practice in OpenStack codebases. - Bandit v0.11.0None.. code-block:: none >> Issue: Use of assert detected. The enclosed code will be removed when compiling to optimised byte code. Severity: Low Confidence: High Location: ./examples/assert.py:1 1 assert True 2 - https://bugs.launchpad.net/juniperopenstack/+bug/1456193 - https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1397883

added_lines: ==================The use of a hard-coded passwords increases the possibility of password guessing tremendously. This plugin test looks for all string littorals and checks to see if they exist in a list of likely default passwords. If they are found in the list, a LOW severity issue is reported. Note: this test is very noisy and likly to result in many false positives. - Bandit v0.9.0This plugin test takes a similarly named config block, `hardcoded_password`. Here a path, `word_list`, can be given to indicate where the default password word list file may be found. # Support for full path, relative path and special "%(site_data_dir)s" # substitution (/usr/{local}/share) word_list: "%(site_data_dir)s/wordlist/default-passwords".. code-block:: none >> Issue: Possible hardcoded password '(root)' Severity: Low Confidence: Low Location: ./examples/hardcoded-passwords.py:5 4 def someFunction2(password): 5 if password == "root": 6 print("OK, logged in")- https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Use_of_hard-coded_password

added_lines: =======================Safely creating a temporary file or directory means following a number of rules (see the references for more details). This plugin test looks for strings starting with (configurable) commonly used temporary paths, for example: - /tmp - /var/tmp - /dev/shm - etc - First introduced in Bandit v0.9.0 - Improved in Bandit v0.13.0This test plugin takes a similarly named config block, `hardcoded_tmp_directory`. The config block provides a Python list, `tmp_dirs`, that lists string fragments indicating possible temporary file paths. Any string starting with one of these fragments will report a MEDIUM confidence issue. tmp_dirs: ['/tmp', '/var/tmp', '/dev/shm'].. code-block: none >> Issue: Probable insecure usage of temp file/directory. Severity: Medium Confidence: Medium Location: ./examples/hardcoded-tmp.py:1 1 f = open('/tmp/abc', 'w') 2 f.write('def') - https://security.openstack.org/guidelines/dg_using-temporary-files-securely.html

subject: Disable pep8 check E127
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-24 22:48:18.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/a3c83578be9044c0739c30303f6d1de4baad89e8', 'message': 'Disable pep8 check E127

Let's say you have some code like this:

class TestStuff(unittest.TestCase):
    def test_a_thing(self):
        # [setup code goes here]
        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
             mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
             mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

pep8 will complain about this with a pair of messages like this: "E127
continuation line over-indented for visual indent", plus some line
numbers. It's complaining about the indentations of the second and
third lines in the 'with' clause.

Okay, so it's over-indented. Let's indent it less.

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
           mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
           mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Now it's uglier, and pep8 still says it's over-indented. Keep going:

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
          mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
          mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Nope.

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
         mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
         mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Still no.

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
        mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
        mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Still no. Different error this time, though.

Okay, let's try adding some spaces to see if that'll make it less...
over-indented. *sigh*

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
              mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
              mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Nope. You sick of this yet? I sure am.

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
               mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
               mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

ARGH

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
                mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
                mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Three spaces works! Hallelujah! How about four?

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
                 mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
                 mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

BAHAHA no.

Got it? When pep8 says that a continuation line is over-indented, you
need to add exactly three spaces. Three shall be the number thou shalt
count, and the number of the counting shall be three. Four shalt thou
not count, neither count thou two, excepting that thou then proceed to
three. Five is right out.

This commit blacklists E127 so nobody else has to waste time on this
garbage.

Change-Id: Ifbcf3c2ee04d9636135ae6dcd606d595acb4b815
'}]
commit_message:
Disable pep8 check E127

Let's say you have some code like this:

class TestStuff(unittest.TestCase):
    def test_a_thing(self):
        # [setup code goes here]
        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
             mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
             mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

pep8 will complain about this with a pair of messages like this: "E127
continuation line over-indented for visual indent", plus some line
numbers. It's complaining about the indentations of the second and
third lines in the 'with' clause.

Okay, so it's over-indented. Let's indent it less.

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
           mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
           mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Now it's uglier, and pep8 still says it's over-indented. Keep going:

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
          mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
          mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Nope.

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
         mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
         mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Still no.

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
        mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
        mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Still no. Different error this time, though.

Okay, let's try adding some spaces to see if that'll make it less...
over-indented. *sigh*

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
              mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
              mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Nope. You sick of this yet? I sure am.

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
               mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
               mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

ARGH

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
                mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
                mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

Three spaces works! Hallelujah! How about four?

        with mock.patch("swift.obj.auditor.os.wait", fake_os_wait), \
                 mock.patch.object(my_auditor, 'fork_child', fake_fork_child), \
                 mock.patch.object(my_auditor, '_sleep', lambda *a: None):
            my_auditor.run_once()

BAHAHA no.

Got it? When pep8 says that a continuation line is over-indented, you
need to add exactly three spaces. Three shall be the number thou shalt
count, and the number of the counting shall be three. Four shalt thou
not count, neither count thou two, excepting that thou then proceed to
three. Five is right out.

This commit blacklists E127 so nobody else has to waste time on this
garbage.

Change-Id: Ifbcf3c2ee04d9636135ae6dcd606d595acb4b815

commit_message:
Add claim for evacuate operations

Nova only set host and node when it wants to evacuate
an instance. Unlink other operations such as unshelve or
create, there is no claim means sometimes the host might
have enough resource will still do the evacuate operations.
This patch adds check for resources when doing evacuate.

Change-Id: Ia7167d8c5f49820907a292663f5c43c852a8e824
Partial-Bug: #1289064

added_lines: def _rebuild_handle(self, **kwargs): try: self.driver.rebuild(**kwargs) except NotImplementedError: # NOTE(rpodolyaka): driver doesn't provide specialized version # of rebuild, fall back to the default implementation self._rebuild_default_impl(**kwargs) # TODO(jichenjc): add filter limits when enable retry limits = {} if recreate: node_name = None try: compute_node = self._get_compute_info(context, self.host) node_name = compute_node.hypervisor_hostname except exception.ComputeHostNotFound: LOG.exception(_LE('Failed to get compute_info for %s'), self.host) if node_name is None: node_name = self.driver.get_available_nodes()[0] LOG.debug('No node specified, defaulting to %s', node_name, instance=instance) rt = self._get_resource_tracker(node_name) try: with rt.instance_claim(context, instance, limits): self._rebuild_handle(**kwargs) except Exception: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.exception(_LE('Instance failed to evacuate'), instance=instance) else: self._rebuild_handle(**kwargs)
deleted_lines: # NOTE(mriedem): On a recreate (evacuate), we need to update # the instance's host and node properties to reflect it's # destination node for the recreate. node_name = None try: compute_node = self._get_compute_info(context, self.host) node_name = compute_node.hypervisor_hostname except exception.ComputeHostNotFound: LOG.exception(_LE('Failed to get compute_info for %s'), self.host) finally: instance.host = self.host instance.node = node_name instance.save() try: self.driver.rebuild(**kwargs) except NotImplementedError: # NOTE(rpodolyaka): driver doesn't provide specialized version # of rebuild, fall back to the default implementation self._rebuild_default_impl(**kwargs)

commit_message:
Add weigher for cached images on Ironic nodes.

Also add accompanying tests.

And a small change to the Ironic driver to load cache information from
hosts, if present.

Change-Id: Ic3f6be60b09fc6ea02ccc6a7c36254d108c84c5e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/81/170681/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 OpenStack Foundation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Cached Image Weigher. Weigh hosts by their cached image. Weighs hosts who have image(s) cached that meet the request specifications. """ from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging from nova.scheduler import weights cached_image_weight_opts = [ cfg.FloatOpt('cached_image_weight_multiplier', default=1.0, help='Multiplier used for weighing cached images.'), ] CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(cached_image_weight_opts) LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class CachedImageWeigher(weights.BaseHostWeigher): minval = 0 def weight_multiplier(self): """Override the weight multiplier.""" return CONF.cached_image_weight_multiplier def _weigh_object(self, host_state, weight_properties): """Hosts with requested images cached return higher weights.""" stats = host_state.stats request_image_id = weight_properties['request_spec']['image']['id'] # If the cached image matches the request, return a positive weight. if (stats.get('cache_status', None) == 'cached' and stats.get('cache_image_id', None) == request_image_id): return 1 # Otherwise we have nothing to say about this instance. return 0

commit_message:
Integrated with PyKMIP Pie API

The PyKMIP Pie API provides a simpler interface for communicating with
KMIP devices. The interface is simplified to allow KMIP integrators to
quickly be able to communicate with a KMIP device. It does not provide
all of the KMIP optional parameters, but those features are not
required for integration with KMIP in the KMIP secret store.

Depends-On: I568a28288068c6016dc67244d979d3619874a425
Change-Id: Ie6f71752eb4d7c7f01942b3881db7a4aa424cb49

commit_message:
PyKMIP 0.4.0 test requirement

PyKMIP has released version 0.4.0 that is required by the KMIP secret
store. Subsequent patches for the KMIP secret store will be submitted
that utilize the new features.

The 0.4.0 release of PyKMIP includes a new Pie API that is as easy as
pie to use. The KMIP secret store will utilize this functionality.

Change-Id: I568a28288068c6016dc67244d979d3619874a425

upstream module: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/218899)

Add support to the base image for RHEL

Add support to the base image for running RHEL containers.  Document
how to register a system with RHN in image-buliding.rst.

Change-Id: Id69c114cf734a8242066b8d7d05ba19c07af036a
Partially-Implements: blueprint rhel-based-image-support

added_lines: To build RHEL containers, it is necessary to use the -i (include header) feature to include registration with RHN of the container runtime operating system. To obtain a RHN username/password/pool id, contact Red Hat. First create a file called rhel-include: :: RUN subscription-manager register --user=<user-name> --password=<password> RUN subscription-manager attach --pool <pool-id> THen build RHEL containers: :: build -b rhel -i ./rhel-include

commit_message:
Update the minimum glanceclient version

A bug is present in glanceclient versions 0.16.1 and 0.17.0 which means
that https connections can not be established between nova and glance,
causing API requests to fail.

Bump the minimum supported version to prevent users hitting this issue.

Conflicts:
	global-requirements.txt

Change-Id: Id10e46166b90e67b013512476fb546f463316a1e
Related-bug: 1442664
(cherry picked from commit e586a0a72774578e2d1d8b399538eb39c4b88492)

commit_message:
Updating stable/juno glance_store cap

glance_store 0.3.0 was recently released and the team is also moving to
maintaining stable branches for this library. Therefore, this patch
bumps the stable version for glance_store to <0.4.0 so that it pulls in
0.3.0 and all its future patches releases.

Change-Id: I43ff0df7fe802e585bb1042abc908ad0bb9a7e81

commit_message:
Adding 'Advanced python scheduler' (apscheduler) to global requirement

 * Library that enable creating scheduled job in seconds granularity

 * License : MIT

 * Requires: six, futures, pytz, tzlocal

 * Last version 3.0.3 (2015-04-27)

 * Is the library python 3 compatible ? Yes

 * Project :mistral

Change-Id: Ifeaea86afcacd8d0b653565837d63ee6c374f587
Implements: blueprint cron-trigger-seconds-granularity

subject: Add sphinx_rtd_theme to enhance doc gate jobs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-13 10:06:00.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/73ef86cf7b5f0bdd7a7a22fd8d042b4ef22ad6db', 'message': 'Add sphinx_rtd_theme to enhance doc gate jobs

When it gets to submitting & reviewing patches for the project documentation,
it is very convenient to surf through the docs generated by Sphinx in a special
Gate job. The problem is that Sphinx uses in gates a theme which is different
from that used on ReadTheDocs. So the docs generated in gates look differently
from the docs that we have on ReadTheDocs, while the desired behaviour is to
have the same Sphinx theme both on ReadTheDocs and in gates.

There is a snippet that enables this theme for Sphinx locally (and so in gates):
http://paste.openstack.org/show/156901/

'}]
commit_message:
Add sphinx_rtd_theme to enhance doc gate jobs

When it gets to submitting & reviewing patches for the project documentation,
it is very convenient to surf through the docs generated by Sphinx in a special
Gate job. The problem is that Sphinx uses in gates a theme which is different
from that used on ReadTheDocs. So the docs generated in gates look differently
from the docs that we have on ReadTheDocs, while the desired behaviour is to
have the same Sphinx theme both on ReadTheDocs and in gates.

There is a snippet that enables this theme for Sphinx locally (and so in gates):
http://paste.openstack.org/show/156901/

It is going to be used, for example, here:
https://review.openstack.org/120018

This code uses the sphinx_rtd_theme python package, so we need to include it
into global requirements.

Change-Id: I61dad599279b0dd94a70adcfd415f5a97701a5c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/08/146808/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sphinx_rtd_theme

commit_message:
Use diff --exit-code instead of --quiet

git diff --quiet has been reported to not return the expected exit
status in some circumstances (see
https://bugs.launchpad.net/devstack/+bug/1264422). This change matches
what devstack does, and uses --exit-code instead of --quiet.

This has also been submitted to openstack-dev/pbr
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/146958/).

Change-Id: I149b3b5faa793eb2b6b8e0ae636f5e93a2f1fb71
Related-Bug: #1410434
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/69/146969/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # git diff --quiet was reported to be buggy under some circumstances. # use --exit-code instead and ignore the output. if ! git diff --exit-code >/dev/null ; then

commit_message:
Update global requirements to reflect requirements of AMQP1 driver

oslo.messaging AMQP1 driver has its own requirements, so it does
make sense to reflect them in global requirements

Here's a list of missing requirements:
- Requirement pyngus>=1.0.0,<2.0.0 not in openstack/requirements
- Requirement python-qpid-proton>=0.7,<0.8 not in openstack/requirements

Requirements list can be generated using project-config
check-requirements tool (see references below).

Change-Id: Ie6768b54a5638b07af2a93d68cc2857d6a49ed76
Needed-By: I893f9a1c259157bc6e6829fe34067ede365c15b7 (project-config)
Caused-By: I9708322308655cbb4832fec1351ea1215e6e11ef (oslo.messaging)

commit_message:
Move puppet call into own script

Allowing other script to simply invoke puppet apply.

Change-Id: I22b035340b9145bf1bfe63db2d4868585ccf077b
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/02/186602/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash -xe # Copyright (C) 2011-2013 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. SUDO=${SUDO:-true} THIN=${THIN:-true} ALL_MYSQL_PRIVS=${ALL_MYSQL_PRIVS:-false} set +e if [ -z "$NODEPOOL_SSH_KEY" ] ; then sudo puppet apply --detailed-exitcodes --modulepath=/root/system-config/modules:/etc/puppet/modules \ -e "class {'openstack_project::single_use_slave': sudo => $SUDO, thin => $THIN, all_mysql_privs => $ALL_MYSQL_PRIVS, }" PUPPET_RET_CODE=$? else sudo puppet apply --detailed-exitcodes --modulepath=/root/system-config/modules:/etc/puppet/modules \ -e "class {'openstack_project::single_use_slave': install_users => false, sudo => $SUDO, thin => $THIN, all_mysql_privs => $ALL_MYSQL_PRIVS, ssh_key => '$NODEPOOL_SSH_KEY', }" PUPPET_RET_CODE=$? fi # Puppet doesn't properly return exit codes. Check here the values that # indicate failure of some sort happened. 0 and 2 indicate success. if [ "$PUPPET_RET_CODE" -eq "4" ] || [ "$PUPPET_RET_CODE" -eq "6" ] ; then exit $PUPPET_RET_CODE fi set -e

commit_message:
Remove last vestige of glanceclient being different

There is an ongoing transition across OpenStack from endpoint_type
to interface. New glanceclient uses the new form, so we support both
and can remove the copy/pasta in the glance_client constructor.

Change-Id: I63f70a0102eb7d7982eacf28ff14642550942911
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/91/219291/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_client( self, service_key, client_class, interface_key='endpoint_type'): try: interface = self.cloud_config.get_interface(service_key) constructor_args = dict( constructor_args[interface_key] = interface client = client_class(**constructor_args) if self._glance_client is None: self._glance_client = self._get_client( 'image', glanceclient.Client, interface_key='interface')
deleted_lines: def _get_client(self, service_key, client_class): try: client = client_class( endpoint_type=self.cloud_config.get_interface(service_key), service_key = 'image' try: # trigger exception on lack of service self.get_session_endpoint(service_key) self._glance_client = glanceclient.Client( version=self.cloud_config.get_api_version(service_key), session=self.keystone_session, service_name=self.cloud_config.get_service_name(service_key), service_type=self.cloud_config.get_service_type(service_key), interface=self.cloud_config.get_interface(service_key), region_name=self.region_name) except Exception: self.log.debug( "Couldn't construct {service} object".format( service=service_key), exc_info=True) raise if self._glance_client is None: raise OpenStackCloudException( "Failed to instantiate {service} client." " This could mean that your credentials are wrong.".format( service=service_key))

commit_message:
Fix exception lists in functional tests

There is a pattern in our functional tests where exceptions are
aggregated within a list and then joined within a single string.
However, the join expects them as strings, not as exception objects.
When this code is hit, it causes an exception:

TypeError: sequence item 0: expected string, OpenStackCloudException found

This change converts those exception objects to strings.

Change-Id: I0a041a61537b79c73615e5136492141da0926fee

commit_message:
Replace deprecated SortedDict with OrderedDict

Class django.utils.datastructures.SortedDict is deprecated since
Django 1.7 (removed in Django 1.9) and should be replaced with
collections.OrderedDict.

Closes-Bug: #1492270

Change-Id: Ib1c0c898c716803bf9c39827d588351c332993db
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/10/220510/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from collections import OrderedDict full_flavors = OrderedDict([(str(flavor.id), flavor) for flavor in flavors]) image_map = OrderedDict([(str(image.id), image) for image in images]) return OrderedDict((str(flavor.id), flavor) for flavor in flavors)
deleted_lines: from django.utils.datastructures import SortedDict full_flavors = SortedDict([(str(flavor.id), flavor) for flavor in flavors]) image_map = SortedDict([(str(image.id), image) for image in images]) return SortedDict((str(flavor.id), flavor) for flavor in flavors)

commit_message:
libvirt: add more logging and result checking around attachDeviceFlags

This is really grasping at straws but commit ef9dedb2f which introduced
this code in the guest module changed passing flags from a positional
argument to a kwarg and we're wondering if that is somehow messing up
how PyArg_ParseTuple is handling this - like maybe the underlying
libvirt just never gets called.

Also adds return code checking on attachDeviceFlags since if it's not
failing and raising libvirtError, we want to make sure it's at least
returning 0, and not something unexpected like None.

Log the flags while we're at it.

Related-Bug: #1492026

Change-Id: I04688f50b70dfbe19f2fcac8c9bc12c0940ef4fd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/57/220357/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Return code from attachDeviceFlags: ' '%(rc)s') % {'conf': xml, 'guest': self.uuid, 'rc': rc}) raise exception.NovaException(msg)

commit_message:
acceptance: enable debug & verbosity for OpenStack logs

Enable debug & verbose when possible for OpenStack services logs, so we can read a maximum
of informations in Jenkins jobs logs and easily debug our eventual failures.

Change-Id: Ifd0b772f9425ce7aacd3c9fff57167012e433ea6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-manila refs/changes/09/213509/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: debug => true, verbose => true,

commit_message:
turn multi host true for nova network by default

With multi host set to true devstack's dnsmasq server no longer
listens on the network to other systems. In the gate we can see we're
getting a ton of spurious dhcp requests from other systems on the
network, and it's better that we never even see it.

Change-Id: Ie600de91e4a7da734eae722e78101c2401a7b1f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/60/218860/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add 'rhel' for RPM distros

Add 'rhel' to list for RPM based distros.  Also sort the distro
list for rpm packages for affected lines.

Change-Id: Ied4cb3e9763d6c6359f314d16185383ac3e006ed
Partially-Implements: blueprint rhel-based-image-support

commit_message:
Fix murano devstack libs and plugin

The root cause of the problem is deprecation of multiple
options in python-openstackclient
This patch fixes endpoint creation and service creation in
devstack-related libs and plugin

Change-Id: I4b1e5388b3321b77146bfcec7219ca5331b70b84
Closes-Bug: #1492209

commit_message:
Remove Local flow installation From the L2 Agent to L3 Controller

Move the flow installation for translating the tunnel id
into the nicira extension marking, from the local l2 agent into the
L3 application using OpenFlow RYU framework.

This patch is dependent on the commit of the following patch in RYU
https://github.com/osrg/ryu/commit/815dc505b750ed7ea61d01ee7eaf767de6b377cc
Note: require upgrade of the Ryu lib to the latest stable to solve the
bug but version check was added to support older ryu version on the
stable branch

Closes-Bug: #1480786
Change-Id: I909e1adce889685c17aba528ace1ebb7d0ed52a2
(cherry picked from commit 4183e65ce360800ec915e65531c0e28fc3f2e152)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/67/212067/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: if self.patch_tun_ofport > 0: # Mark the tunnel ID so the data will be transferred to the # br-tun virtual switch, tun id and metadata are local bridge.add_flow(table="60", priority=1, actions="move:NXM_NX_TUN_ID[0..31]" "->NXM_NX_PKT_MARK[]," "output:%s" % (self.patch_tun_ofport))

commit_message:
Compute v2.1 docs clean up

  Remove create_backup              (duplication)
  Remove extended-availability-zone (legacy v2 only)
  Remove extended-server-attributes (legacy v2 only)
  Remove extended-status            (legacy v2 only)
  Remove extended-volume            (legacy v2 only)

Change-Id: Ie42123fd45d54afaec0fc5edbdcdcb6114a6e19d
Implements: blueprint compute-vmware-role
'}]
commit_message:
[VMware] Compute VMware role

1. adds Deploying nova-compute on a standalone node
2. restructures the Nodes tab section
3. improves rts formatting - removes grey lines from the Deploying
   vCenter section
4. removes the screen captures that do not bring any additional
   information to that explained in text

Change-Id: Ie42123fd45d54afaec0fc5edbdcdcb6114a6e19d
Implements: blueprint compute-vmware-role

commit_message:
[gates] Convert Rally to the new Devstack plugin model

Switch Rally integration with Devstack to the new plugin model [1].
This allows to install Rally by one line in localrc, without
copying any files by hand. It also may make setting CI jobs easier.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/devstack/plugins.html

* Remove Sahara pluging from Rally gate job

Sahara was removed from default services that run DevStack in gates
We need to remove these scenarios from rally.yaml and add separate job
for Sahara

Depends-on: I845178bd51f2623fa56bb97f8bd5f2e4e7553613
Change-Id: Ia4e211dbf50d13068502c27c26cf5e3199542ce7

commit_message:
Additional retries for ssh wait check

This patch adds additional retries to the ssh wait check
tasks which were unintentionally omitted from
https://review.openstack.org/218572

Change-Id: Id8f7df5e283a9f61373f1bfb167a4c0bd098cc25
Closes-Bug: #1490142
(cherry picked from commit 91fc87ae3825ac4e59b2e6e18e4e7ff8e3dc1e5b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/30/220430/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: register: ssh_wait_check until: ssh_wait_check|success retries: 3

commit_message:
Role * supported for deployment tasks

JSON schema for role changed. We support '*' or list
of tasks names in role field.
Duplication of test 'test_check_group_type_deployment_task' removed.

Change-Id: I32321826e5e8b45ea0e5d6cc2e1361fba9cbce14
Closes-Bug: #1492167

commit_message:
enable nova v20 compat testing jobs

Create 2 Nova v2.0 compatibility jobs. These will test, on Nova only,
that v2.0 on v2.1 and v2.0 on legacy v2.0 code pass all the Tempest
API tests.

Depends-On: Ie6b7e4290d9a1d9789d04099b3b31c9a557bc22b

devstack changes

and

Depends-On: I94b1305882598cc259a267dc8e954ab242baf7d1

which are Nova changes that setup the pipelines the way we expect

Change-Id: I86a627b8ec7b1246452a16c10dcfb1ad5f83bdef

commit_message:
Implement /usr/bin/env as the shebang in all bash scripts

In order to be more consistent, and also account for different
environments and platforms, this patch implements the use of
environment.

Closes-Bug: #1485557
Change-Id: I93e6a47fd6be816620682eddb2880e38f11bf675
(cherry picked from commit d1f410d08a5369c1a25bbd15da318b247003514a)

subject: Ensure rsync restarts fully during swift setup
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-03 18:04:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/bd5e35d10baa46deaa03e5156a2ff9c81404e050', 'message': 'Ensure rsync restarts fully during swift setup

Existing rsync stop/start handlers were relying on the pattern
parameter to the Ansible service module which relies on the results
of ps to determine if the service is running. This is unnecessary
because the rsync service script is well-behaved and responds
appropriately to start stop and restart commands. Removal of the
pattern param ensures that the response from the service command is
used instead.

Root cause of the bug is that when Keystone was changed to share
fernet secrets via rsync over ssh tunnel, an rsync process was
introduced in AIOs, Swift stand-alones, and other deployment
configurations that contain Keystone containers on the storage hosts.

The resulting rsync processes within Keystone containers pollute the
results of ps commands on the host, fooling Ansible into thinking
that an rsync service is running on the standard port when it is not.

Secondly, the handler responsible for stopping rsync was not causing
the notice for "Ensure rsync service running" to trigger cleanly in
my testing, so the tasks were changed to trigger both notices in an
ordered list.

Change-Id: I5ed47f7c1974d6b22eeb2ff5816ee6fa30ee9309
Closes-Bug: 1481121
(cherry picked from commit f32a31d58546838f7fa951d0801fb24571b315cf)

The resulting rsync processes within Keystone containers pollute the

that an rsync service is running on the standard port when it is not.

Secondly, the handler responsible for stopping rsync was not causing
the notice for "Ensure rsync service running" to trigger cleanly in

commit_message:
Ensure rsync restarts fully during swift setup

Existing rsync stop/start handlers were relying on the pattern
parameter to the Ansible service module which relies on the results
of ps to determine if the service is running. This is unnecessary
because the rsync service script is well-behaved and responds
appropriately to start stop and restart commands. Removal of the
pattern param ensures that the response from the service command is
used instead.

Root cause of the bug is that when Keystone was changed to share
fernet secrets via rsync over ssh tunnel, an rsync process was
introduced in AIOs, Swift stand-alones, and other deployment
configurations that contain Keystone containers on the storage hosts.

The resulting rsync processes within Keystone containers pollute the
results of ps commands on the host, fooling Ansible into thinking
that an rsync service is running on the standard port when it is not.

Secondly, the handler responsible for stopping rsync was not causing
the notice for "Ensure rsync service running" to trigger cleanly in
my testing, so the tasks were changed to trigger both notices in an
ordered list.

Change-Id: I5ed47f7c1974d6b22eeb2ff5816ee6fa30ee9309
Closes-Bug: 1481121
(cherry picked from commit f32a31d58546838f7fa951d0801fb24571b315cf)

commit_message:
Add sorting_method to swift proxy config as needed

When read_affinity is used and sorting_method is not used warnings
are generated in the swift proxy log indicating that the
read_affinity is not being respected. When read_affinity is specified
this change sets the sorting_method to affinity automatically, and
otherwise uses a configured value which defaults to shuffle.

Note that write_affinity does not respect sorting_method and follows
a different code path and does not issue warnings in logs when used
without sorting_method.

Closes-bug: 1480581
Co-Authored-By: Andy McCrae <andy.mccrae@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I3cab89c95f288b4a59f4dd3c7360daca7a4f47bf
(cherry picked from commit 39b0e5d4438624a6a981c3ae4606b7ce200cbe28)

commit_message:
Update kilo for new dev work - 4 Sep 2015

Updates all repo SHAs for new work on 11.2.2, including the
fix for https://launchpad.net/bugs/1490380 and thereby removing
the related temporary pin introduced in
https://review.openstack.org/217014

Change-Id: I6ca5ec2585acf6e748f98c315e88f4c247445557

subject: libvirt: Fix migration when image doesn't exist
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-09 20:32:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/73232e7ad1b9a29ddf6621c3c1216309d4485b58', 'message': "libvirt: Fix migration when image doesn't exist

When nova is used without shared_storage and glance doesn't have the
images required by the instance anymore, the live block migration code
can't prepare the destination host properly.

This patch catches the case when images are not found in glance, and
copies the missing images from the source host, like the
migrate_disk_and_power_off code already does.

The KVM disk deep copy method is not used because it won't work for AMI
image that depends of AKI/ARI image. kernel and initrd are not considered
by the kvm disk migration because they are readonly file (by the kvm pov)
used only to boot the VM.

Co-Authored-By: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@cloudwatt.com>
Closes-bug: #1270825

Change-Id: If81f8b1bbe3e738579ffe2d8f36807afb77560d8
(cherry picked from commit 3345ca029fd2527eec8de365a37779fd37809398)
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-06-10 03:00:57.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py', 'nova/virt/libvirt/utils.py', 'nova/tests/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7bab2c124e083ff2d401a6bb9e51fed61979aa2d', 'message': "libvirt: Fix migration when image doesn't exist

When nova is used without shared_storage and glance doesn't have the
images required by the instance anymore, the live block migration code
can't prepare the destination host properly.

This patch catches the case when images are not found in glance, and
copies the missing images from the source host, like the
migrate_disk_and_power_off code already does.

The KVM disk deep copy method is not used because it won't work for AMI
image that depends of AKI/ARI image. kernel and initrd are not considered
by the kvm disk migration because they are readonly file (by the kvm pov)
used only to boot the VM.

Co-Authored-By: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@cloudwatt.com>
Closes-bug: #1270825

Change-Id: If81f8b1bbe3e738579ffe2d8f36807afb77560d8
(cherry picked from commit 3345ca029fd2527eec8de365a37779fd37809398)
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Fix migration when image doesn't exist

When nova is used without shared_storage and glance doesn't have the
images required by the instance anymore, the live block migration code
can't prepare the destination host properly.

This patch catches the case when images are not found in glance, and
copies the missing images from the source host, like the
migrate_disk_and_power_off code already does.

The KVM disk deep copy method is not used because it won't work for AMI
image that depends of AKI/ARI image. kernel and initrd are not considered
by the kvm disk migration because they are readonly file (by the kvm pov)
used only to boot the VM.

Co-Authored-By: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@cloudwatt.com>
Closes-bug: #1270825

Change-Id: If81f8b1bbe3e738579ffe2d8f36807afb77560d8
(cherry picked from commit 3345ca029fd2527eec8de365a37779fd37809398)

commit_message:
Wrap IPv6 address in square brackets for scp/rsync

Address, contained in nova.netconf.my_ip config option, is passed to
scp/rsync when copying image during migration.  If this option contains
IPv6 address, scp/rsync fails.

Wrapping IPv6 address in square brackets solves this problem.  Code was
adopted from swift project.

Change-Id: Ia5f28673e79158d948980f2b3ce496c6a56882af
Closes-Bug: #1422691
(cherry picked from commit ca3862cd2a8086fff712efe79e0bf013eda33505)

commit_message:
Add posting measures to live gabbi test

For those storage backends that use metricd this will ensure that
metricd sees some action in the dsvm-functional tests.

In order for some backends to work (notably ceph) the
gnocchi-metricd service cannot run in a virtualenv so now nothing
will run in a virtualenv.

Change-Id: If53e2613a1dd103baa8652dbd916e1f9901fc2be
Related-Bug: #1488510

commit_message:
set compute catalog to use current nova API

set the compute catalog to use nova v2.1 API. Because nova has
tenant_id in the service catalog it's not so simple to just use an
unversioned thing. But at least this will mean we're running the new
code.

Change-Id: I5b73a2161f021a112ec879cba6e5d99ffd548a6a

commit_message:
iniset $BOTO_CONF in a temp dir to avoid permission issues

iniset will fail in /etc because sed can't create temporary
files in /etc. Instead copy the file to a temporary location
and change it there. While ugly, this is preferrable to
using sudo on every iniset or passing in a sudo flag to iniset
for a single use case.

Change-Id: I5f4c43bbbe477c570936e2e40ac05cc38febbb3f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/15/187215/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add migration policy to upgrades devref

Added a set of schema and data migration policy rules to the `upgrades`
devref document to facilitate live upgrades.

Change-Id: I4e38a228b38927115bb13652966d45f250cc2af6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/62/218362/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Migration policy: ''''''''''''''''' The following guidelines for schema and data migrations are followed in order to ease upgrades: * Additive schema migrations - In general, almost all schema migrations should be additive. Put simply, they should only create elements like columns, indices, and tables. * Subtractive schema migrations - To remove an element like a column or table during the N release cycle: #. The element must be deprecated and retained for backward compatibility. (This allows for graceful upgrade from N to N+1.) #. Data migration, by the objects layer, must completely migrate data from the old version of the schema to the new version. #. The column can then be removed with a migration at the start of N+2. * Data migrations - As mentioned above, data migrations will be done in an online fashion by custom code in the object layer that handles moving data between the old and new portions of the schema. In addition, for each type of data migration performed, there should exist a nova-manage option for an operator to manually request that rows be migrated. *Future* work - #. Adding plumbing to enforce that relevant data migrations are completed before running `contract` in the expand/migrate/contract schema migration workflow.

commit_message:
Rename tests so that they are run

Several tests in test_common.py weren't given names starting with
'test_', so testr won't find them. This patch simply adds the 'test_'
prefix to these tests.

commit_message:
Adds unit tests to test_common.py

The test coverage of nova/api/openstack/common.py skipped several
methods involving link manipulation. This patch adds more tests to
better cover the code.

Partial-Bug: 1489627
Change-Id: Ie73a391ba2f3bc10bb5d89761ebba9e1b23018dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/218307/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.tests.unit.api.openstack import fakes class ViewBuilderLinkTest(test.NoDBTestCase): project_id = "fake" api_version = "2.1" def setUp(self): super(ViewBuilderLinkTest, self).setUp() self.request = self.req("/%s" % self.project_id) self.vb = common.ViewBuilder() def req(self, url, use_admin_context=False): return fakes.HTTPRequest.blank(url, use_admin_context=use_admin_context, version=self.api_version) def test_get_project_id(self): proj_id = self.vb._get_project_id(self.request) self.assertEqual(self.project_id, proj_id) def test_get_next_link(self): identifier = "identifier" collection = "collection" next_link = self.vb._get_next_link(self.request, identifier, collection) expected = "/".join((self.request.url, "%s?marker=%s" % (collection, identifier))) self.assertEqual(expected, next_link) def test_get_href_link(self): identifier = "identifier" collection = "collection" href_link = self.vb._get_href_link(self.request, identifier, collection) expected = "/".join((self.request.url, collection, identifier)) self.assertEqual(expected, href_link) def test_get_bookmark_link(self): identifier = "identifier" collection = "collection" bookmark_link = self.vb._get_bookmark_link(self.request, identifier, collection) bmk_url = common.remove_trailing_version_from_href( self.request.application_url) expected = "/".join((bmk_url, self.project_id, collection, identifier)) self.assertEqual(expected, bookmark_link)

doc/source/api and doc/build are build artifacts from building the docs
using the tox -e docs target. These are ignored in .gitignore since we
don't care about them from build to build - but leaving them around can
actually make the docs build fail if modules no longer exist but are

commit_message:
Remove doc/source/api and doc/build before building docs

doc/source/api and doc/build are build artifacts from building the docs
using the tox -e docs target. These are ignored in .gitignore since we
don't care about them from build to build - but leaving them around can
actually make the docs build fail if modules no longer exist but are
still sitting in these directories.

So this change just cleans those up each time you run tox -e docs.

Closes-Bug: #1488637

Change-Id: I646ae0b77a472c425d23815316e804b09bbe867d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/57/216857/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rm rm -rf doc/source/api doc/build

subject: Fix cfntools command injection
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-11 06:11:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-cfntools/commit/4fddaed1f24693abaa1b7c0f841f8c718cf6d87f', 'message': "Fix cfntools command injection

The CommandRunner used to run commands using su command and passing the
actual command to be run as argument to it.

su USER -c <cmd>

This is susceptible to command line injection as noted in the bug.

The fix required to do two things:

1. Pass the command to be run as list instead of a string. This makes
sure that the arguments are passed as arguments to the command ought to
be executed. This will avoid running any command passed as argument. On
the contrary, if the command were passed as a string to the shell, the
arguments could be formed in a way to execute malicious commands.

2. The CommandRunner runs the command directly and uses setuid to lower
the privileges if needed. If the 'runas' user is other than root, then
its UID is obtained and setuid is invoked to set the real user-id and
effective user-id to the given user.

Change-Id: I654117e994fd38411508dbe9b85d06c28dc0e411
Closes-Bug: #1312246

commit_message:
Fix cfntools command injection

The CommandRunner used to run commands using su command and passing the
actual command to be run as argument to it.

su USER -c <cmd>

This is susceptible to command line injection as noted in the bug.

The fix required to do two things:

1. Pass the command to be run as list instead of a string. This is to
ensure that the actual arguments are passed as arguments to the program
ought to be executed. And by doing so, avoids running any commands
passed in the argument. On the contrary, if the command were passed as a
string to the shell, the arguments could be formed in a way to execute
malicious commands.

2. The CommandRunner runs the command directly and uses setuid to lower
the privileges if needed. If the 'runas' user is other than root, then
its UID is obtained and setuid is invoked to set the real user-id and
effective user-id to the given user.

Change-Id: I654117e994fd38411508dbe9b85d06c28dc0e411
Closes-Bug: #1312246

commit_message:
Properly instantiate Forbidden exception

The Forbidden class (and its parent GlanceStoreException) do not take in
any arguments to the init method. Instead, since the message used when
os.unlink fails is different than the default message in the Forbidden
class, a keyword "message" argument needs to be used to properly
instantiate the class.

Change-Id: Iebe1891a61dc4874658065b727b126b72bcd3144
Closes-Bug: #1444663
(cherry picked from commit 5c71f1d2f6fe468aab180c929394a67be2d3fb53)

deleted_lines: raise exceptions.Forbidden(_("You cannot delete file %s") % fn)

commit_message:
Set cinder auth_strategy to keystone explicitely

Default value for auth_strategy changed for Cinder in Liberty
release from 'noauth' to 'keystone'. Therefore relying on
default value makes Cinder fail in Kilo. This patch covers
both releases by setting auth strategy to 'keystone' explicitely

Change-Id: Ic1f45fd43e0a94ca1dbfc63e90e2756c40453352
Closes-Bug: #1492233
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/71/220471/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: auth_strategy = keystone

commit_message:
Add instance save on volume attach

The volume connectors are currently saving some system metadata.  This
is specifically the NPIV connector which uses the system metadata to
store the WWPNs of the VM.

While the spawn and other lifecycle operations call instance.save, the
volume attach and detach do not.  This change provides a save invocation
on the attach.  Detach is not included as it is not critical to the bug
and may have broader impacts for live migration.

It is not put in the npiv volume connector directly as that would
guarantee a save call, when it in fact may not be required.

Change-Id: I970327fbbe1a2fc7d77a6a5951492ec24e31c11a
Closes-Bug: 1491523

commit_message:
Discover version of given compute service type

An admin may specify nova_service_type which doesn't support v2.1. Or
ec2-api can be run against Nova which doesn't support a required
microversion. ec2-api should check this and put warning to log.

This patch does that. If Nova service doesn't suport the required
microversion, ec2-api uses the last microvertions the service supports.
But do not switch to v2 or v2.1 with no microversions at all. This will
be useful for a future cases, when ec2-api uses new features with their
own microversions.

Change-Id: I1cc828b8cad908d9d029c57d514e4ce7e8f47352

Probaly # it should be removed after at least a couple of novaclinet has been # released with no change of APIVersion class location. if not nova_api_versions: logger.warning(_LW('Nova client suports v2.1, but does unexpectedly ' 'not have api_versions module. commit_message:
Update requirements, fix oslo imports and correct tests

Since Blazar was in Winter, lots of tech debt was added.

This big change is actually trying to provide a +1 from Jenkins voting jobs.
ie.

 - fix calls to oslo_config
 - correct unittests failing due to removed assert_called()
 - remove pep8 check for verifying blazar.conf (can be readded later)
 - fix oslo_messaging imports

Not sure it's fully functional, Tempest needs to be fixed too but I
hope the gate will allow that change to pass.

Change-Id: Ib70b5b48b47626fc2613ee894d1162219417994f

commit_message:
Fix duplicated notification

Now when the pooling is enabled, notification will be triggered two
times because the subscription controller of pooling is also in the
pipeline. This patch fixes it by checking the subscription controller
type.

Closes-Bug: #1489686

Change-Id: I55c72e3869e9b0490bcab3bcae571946bda65aa5
