added_lines: (BoolOpt) Send a single AMQP reply to call message. The current behaviour since oslo-incubator is to send two AMQP replies - first one with the payload, a second one to ensure the other have finish to send the payload. We are going to remove it in the N release, but we must keep backward compatible at the same time. This option provides such compatibility - it defaults to False in Liberty and can be turned on for early adopters with a new installations or for testing. Please note, that this option will be removed in the Mitaka release.
deleted_lines: (BoolOpt) Send a single AMQP reply to call message. The current behaviour since oslo-incubator is to send two AMQP replies - first one with the payload, a second one to ensure the other have finish to send the payload. We are going to remove it in the N release, but we must keep backward compatible at the same time. This option provides such compatibility - it defaults to False in Liberty and can be turned on for early adopters with a new installations or for testing. Please note, that this option will be removed in M release.

subject: Ensure rsync restarts fully during swift setup
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-26 18:45:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/e2e7c5a16e3f479f1234181afd412026ca990ab2', 'message': 'Ensure rsync restarts fully during swift setup

Existing rsync stop/start handlers were relying on the pattern
parameter to the Ansible service module which relies on the results
of ps to determine if the service is running. This is unnecessary
because the rsync service script is well-behaved and responds
appropriately to start stop and restart commands. Removal of the
pattern param ensures that the response from the service command is
used instead.

Root cause of the bug is that when Keystone was changed to share
fernet secrets via rsync over ssh tunnel, an rsync process was
introduced in AIOs, Swift stand-alones, and other deployment
configurations that contain Keystone containers on the storage hosts.

The resulting rsync processes within Keystone containers pollute the
results of ps commands on the host, fooling Ansible into thinking
that an rsync service is running on the standard port when it is not.

Secondly, the handler responsible for stopping rsync was not causing
the notice for "Ensure rsync service running" to trigger cleanly in
my testing, so the tasks were changed to trigger both notices in an
ordered list.

Change-Id: I5ed47f7c1974d6b22eeb2ff5816ee6fa30ee9309
Closes-Bug: 1481121

commit_message:
Ensure rsync restarts fully during swift setup

Existing rsync stop/start handlers were relying on the pattern
parameter to the Ansible service module which relies on the results
of ps to determine if the service is running. This is unnecessary
because the rsync service script is well-behaved and responds
appropriately to start stop and restart commands. Removal of the
pattern param ensures that the response from the service command is
used instead.

Root cause of the bug is that when Keystone was changed to share
fernet secrets via rsync over ssh tunnel, an rsync process was
introduced in AIOs, Swift stand-alones, and other deployment
configurations that contain Keystone containers on the storage hosts.

The resulting rsync processes within Keystone containers pollute the
results of ps commands on the host, fooling Ansible into thinking
that an rsync service is running on the standard port when it is not.

Secondly, the handler responsible for stopping rsync was not causing
the notice for "Ensure rsync service running" to trigger cleanly in
my testing, so the tasks were changed to trigger both notices in an
ordered list.

Change-Id: I5ed47f7c1974d6b22eeb2ff5816ee6fa30ee9309
Closes-Bug: 1481121

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-19 19:33:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/bc840c1381e6183ca2e5bb6d5f2f39a99304712b', 'message': 'Make rebuild/evacuate use resource claims

means that we will now be properly tracking resources for

commit_message:
Make rebuild/evacuate use resource claims

We make sure that rebuild now uses claims and resource tracking. This
means that we will now be properly tracking resources for
rebuilt/evacuated instances and will potentially fail if a move of the
instance breaks policy set by the scheduler (an exception would be in
case we bypassed the scheduler).

We also make sure that we update the migration record with the current
status (either success or failure).

On a failure to claim, we will currently just error out the instance
which requires manual intervention, but taking advantage of the retry
mechanism could be added in the future.

Since none of the required args are sent yet, this change is effectively
a no-op, until we change the rebuild_instance RPC method to send the
required data over.

Related-blueprint: migration-fix-resource-tracking
Change-Id: Ia068494b1a4c43123fe172d67a81ac0b60682995
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/70/214770/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def rebuild_claim(self, context, instance, limits=None, image_meta=None, migration=None): """Create a claim for a rebuild operation.""" instance_type = instance.flavor return self._move_claim(context, instance, instance_type, move_type='evacuation', limits=limits, image_meta=image_meta, migration=migration) @utils.synchronized(COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE) # Only look at resize/migrate migration and evacuate records return migration.migration_type in ('resize', 'migration', 'evacuate')
deleted_lines: # Only look at resize/migrate migration records return migration.migration_type in ('resize', 'migration')

commit_message:
compute: Make rebuild consider the node that was passed in

We add some of the keyword args that will need to be passed in for the
claims to work (scheduled_node, limits, and the migration object).

Since we will be sending the node name to the rebuild operation, we
will be able to use it and avoid a DB hit. This commit makes sure we take
advantage of that.

Change-Id: Id51c371f9875b8e2b7f4cda6f7a88273b13bb3af
Related-blueprint: migration-fix-resource-tracking

added_lines: :param snapshot_id: uuid4 id of given snapshot def backup_create(self, volume_id): """Create a volume backup from the volume id. :param volume_id: the given volume id to create a backup """ output = self.cinder('backup-create', params=volume_id) backup = self._get_property_from_output(output) self.addCleanup(self.backup_delete, backup['id']) self.wait_for_backup_status(backup['id'], 'available') return backup def backup_delete(self, backup_id): """Delete specified backup by ID. :param backup_id: the given backup id """ if backup_id in self.cinder('backup-list'): self.cinder('backup-delete', params=backup_id) def wait_for_backup_status(self, backup_id, status, timeout=60): """Wait until backup reaches given status. :param backupt_id: uuid4 id of given backup :param status: expected backup's status :param timeout: timeout in seconds """ start_time = time.time() while time.time() - start_time < timeout: if status in self.cinder('backup-show', params=backup_id): break else: self.fail("Backup %s did not reach status %s after %d seconds." % (backup_id, status, timeout)) def assert_backup_details(self, items): """Check presence of common volume backup properties. :param items: volume backup properties """ values = ('id', 'name', 'volume_id') for value in values: self.assertIn(value, items) def check_backup_deleted(self, backup_id, timeout=60): """Check that backup deleted successfully. :param backup_id: the given backup id :param timeout: timeout in seconds """ try: start_time = time.time() while time.time() - start_time < timeout: if backup_id not in self.cinder('backup-show', params=backup_id): break except exceptions.CommandFailed: pass else: self.fail("Backup %s has not deleted after %d seconds." % (backup_id, timeout))
deleted_lines: :param snapshot_id: uuid4 id of given volume

commit_message:
Allow cinder-backup to use ceph

This change updates ceph_client and os_cinder roles to allow
cinder-backup to use ceph.  We also create a new group called
'cinder_backup' which allows us to only retreive the cinder backup key
if cinder-backup is actually in use.

To use, you would simply need to set cinder_service_backup_driver to
cinder.backup.drivers.ceph in your user_variables.yml file.

NOTE: You will need to update your
      /etc/openstack_deploy/env.d/cinder.yml in order for this change
      to execute successfully.

Change-Id: Ib94effa40208bbc8de0f78c5487316be007adcf1
Closes-Bug: #1481787
Implements: blueprint ceph-block-devices
DocImpact
(cherry picked from commit 44d3f25de6daab8073137c9fc76edcdfc23c716f)

commit_message:
Add sorting_method to swift proxy config as needed

When read_affinity is used and sorting_method is not used warnings
are generated in the swift proxy log indicating that the
read_affinity is not being respected. When read_affinity is specified
this change sets the sorting_method to affinity automatically, and
otherwise uses a configured value which defaults to shuffle.

Note that write_affinity does not respect sorting_method and follows
a different code path and does not issue warnings in logs when used
without sorting_method.

Closes-bug: 1480581
Co-Authored-By: Andy McCrae <andy.mccrae@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I3cab89c95f288b4a59f4dd3c7360daca7a4f47bf

commit_message:
Update path to subunit2html in post_test_hook

Per:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-August/072982.html

The location of subunit2html changed on the images in the gate
so update the path used in the post_test_hook.

Long-term we should just use what's in devstack-gate.

Change-Id: I5e50e7d7ad845aba26403df1df412c0a139a6dc7
Closes-Bug: #1491646

added_lines: self.image_compression = None self.streaming = None if self.image_compression is not None: dev.append(etree.Element("image", compression=self.image_compression)) if self.streaming is not None: dev.append(etree.Element("streaming", mode=self.streaming)) class LibvirtConfigGuestVideo(LibvirtConfigGuestDevice): def __init__(self, **kwargs): super(LibvirtConfigGuestVideo, self).__init__(root_name="video", **kwargs) self.type = "qxl" self.vram = "65536" self.accel3d = "yes" self.accel2d = "yes" def format_dom(self): dev = super(LibvirtConfigGuestVideo, self).format_dom() model = etree.Element("model", type=self.type, vram=self.vram, heads="1") model.append(etree.Element("acceleration", accel3d=self.accel3d, accel2d=self.accel2d)) dev.append(model) return dev

commit_message:
Murano versioning

This specification proposes set of arrangements that are going to allow Murano
keep backward compatibility with applications written for older version while
still making possible to introduce incompatible changes to any part of the
project

Change-Id: I5ac638974a3fbd5a75750f7ef5cb7a84299db499
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-specs refs/changes/02/140402/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Murano versioning ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/murano/+spec/murano-versioning This specification proposes set of arrangements that are going to allow Murano keep backward compatibility with applications written for older version while still making possible to introduce incompatible changes to any part of the project. Problem description =================== Murano is a complex system that comprises from a number of services and technologies including several domain specific/markup languages. All of them evolve and change from release to release. New futures are introduced, code is being refactored and not always remains compatible with previous release. But applications written for previous Murano versions must still work on newer releases otherwise all applications would require at least retesting and often code changes on each release. Proposed change =============== Because there are many different parts in Murano that can break and need versioning support to manage backward compatibility. Murano packages versioning '''''''''''''''''''''''''' Version of Murano package is stored in package manifest in **PackageVersion** attribute. The only purpose of this attribute is to indicate compatibility between different versions of the same package. Two packages are said to be compatible if package of a newer version can be used instead of package with lower version number. MuranoPL classes also have versions that are always equal to a version of package they located in. Version string has a form **major.minor.revision** with default “1.0.0”. Version numbers have a strong semantics. I.e. there are strict rules on when those numbers can be changed. Major version number indicated a breaking change in package API. It is incremented when one of the following happens: * Class is removed from package * Public method or property is removed from any class in the package * Public method changes argument signature to incompatible with previous one. For example argument removed or added without default value * Any other change (including in class behavior) that can break class consumers (callers) Classes of different major version are assumed to be incompatible until it is explicitly stated to be compatible or adapter class exists that can be used to transform the class to a newer version. Minor version change means change that is compatible with existing consumers (callers) but not necessary with class descendants. It is incremented when one of the following happens: * New class is introduced in the package * New method or property is introduced in any package’s class * Record added to “Extends” list of any class * Any other interface (including behavior) change that doesn’t break external class users but can possibly break class inheritors Revision number is changed when the package remains compatible with both callers and descendants but introduces behavior changes: * Any changes in class implementation (in workflow, scripts, resources, license, logo, UI forms etc.) that cannot break class consumers and inheritors but affect user experience and/or modifies functionality provided by the class * Default value of property/argument changed If minor or revision parts are absent they assumed to be equal to 0. Thus None = 1 = 1.0 = 1.0.0 and 1.0 = 1.0.0 < 1.0.1 < 1.1.0 < 1.1.100 < 1.2.1 Minor number must be reset to zero with each major version increment but revision is not and thus can be made monotonic. Also there is no requirement to increment versions by 1 and this may be used to indicate significance of change (for example major version by 100 for real big changes while incrementing by 1 if the classes are incompatible only in some rare corner case. Note that it really doesn’t matter how small or big the change was. It might be the case when major version is incremented for negligible change while major improvement will result only in revision number change. Because of this is might have sense to add another version attribute (say free-form **DisplayVersion**) that would contain user-facing version that would not be interpreted by the engine. Besides PackageVersion there is also an optional **ReleaseDate** attribute in package manifest that contains ISO-8601 formatted value. Typically this value is put into package manifest by package assembly script that uses date-time of a last commit to modify the package. If the attribute is absent upload date-time is used instead. The purpose of this attribute is to have ability to release hot-patches/security fixes that would have exactly the same PackageVersion but later ReleaseDate and thus will completely replace older package Class compatibility ''''''''''''''''''' Each MuranoPL class will have optional attribute **CompatibleVersion** defying the lowest **major** version number this class is compatible with. The class assumed to be compatible with all major versions in between CompatibleVersion and class own version. If the attribute is absent it is assumed to equal to major version component of the class itself. In other words it is compatible within single major version. Here term compatibility means compatibility from a point of view of external consumers. Package requirements '''''''''''''''''''' Packages may require other packages for their work. Those requirements are expressed via **Require** key in package manifest. It has a form of Require: package1_FQN: version_string ... packageN_FQN: version_string Upon package upload/validation it is checked that required package exist. It is required that package with exactly the same major and minor version be found and revision number must not be less than the specified. Thus requirement of version = “1” is invalid, and “1.0” is okay. All packages considered to be dependent on “io.murano” package. If such requirement is absent from the list (or the list is empty or even there is no Require key in package manifest) then dependency “io.murano: 1.0” (core library) is automatically added (for package types other than MuranoPL default version may differ) Object version '''''''''''''' Object in Object Model are also versioned using class version (= package version) of a class used to instantiate the object. The version is stored in “?”/”classVersion” attribute of each object. If it is not present “1.0.0” is assumed. Side by side versioning of packages ''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''' Package versioning implies that several versions of the same package (and in turn of the same class) can be used simultaneously. Currently application catalog requires fully qualified class name to be unique but with versioning the pair (FQN, version) must be unique. Packages with release date greater than the release date of existing class with the same name and version it is automatically overwritten by uploaded package otherwise an error raised (displayed). When one class inherits another or instantiates an object of another class the following is done: 1. From application catalog index it is inferred a FQN of package containing the class 2. If found package is of the same name as our package use the class from our package 3. Otherwise from available versions of found package select those having the same major and minor version as specified in package requirement 4. If requirement is specified using 3-part version string prefer the version with the exact version match 5. If there is no exact version match use version with largest revision number available. If requirement was specified using 2-part version string assume revision number to equal to 0. 6. If appropriate version was not found by this time the warning is issued. If the class is present in one of a packages in Require list but there is no matching version the latest version with the same major version component is used. This behavior can be disabled in Murano config. If it is not then the latest version used (this requires even more permissive configuration setting that should not be set by default). 7. Fail as a last resort Note that if class appeared in different packages over time all of them combined into a single list. When the class in expected to be passed from outside (using class() contract of property/argument) the following is done: 1. From application catalog index it is inferred a FQN of package containing the class 2. Examine version of a passed object. If the major version component is equal and minor version that is greater or equal to to that from package requirement use the object. 3. If object has a higher major version see object’s class definition if it is explicitly stated to be compatible with our (older) major version. Otherwise try to build shortest adapter chain to transform older class to required version. 4. If we failed to get compatible version to this point fail with contract violation error Class adapters '''''''''''''' Adapters are special classes that convert between interfaces of incompatible versions of the same class. Adapters are one way e.g. convert from exactly one major version to the version of itself. Adapter classes are ordinary MuranoPL classes that inherit target class and provided with an instance of a source class. Usually the class override incompatible methods to transform them into a calls to an inner object of an older type. Adapter classes are separate from regular classes, put into a special “Adapters” folder inside package and treated specially by the engine. They cannot be instantiated directly and used implicitly as part of contract handling code and cast() function. Adapter classes have additional attribute to indicate source class version and enjoy additional syntax sugar to simplify their development that is not available to regular classes. Such feature will probably require some additions to MuranoPL (like property getters to return property values of inner object) that are planned independently of versioning. Class adapters may be chained to convert between a distant versions. Engine always tries to build a shortest chain of adapters. For example if there are adapters 1 -> 4, 4 -> 5 and 4 -> 6 then if the engine wants to convert from version 2 to version 6 it will use 1(2) -> 4 => 4 -> 6 chain rather than 1(2) -> 4 => 4 -> 5 => 4(5) -> 6 Adapters are indexed separately by the app catalog. Exact syntax for adapters are yet to be designed. Engine versioning ''''''''''''''''' Each package has a manifest attribute named **Format** of a form [PackageType/]Version where PackageType is a language used for the package with “MuranoPL” as a default and Version is a 3-component version string similar to that of package versions with a similar semantics and same shortening rules (None = 1 = 1.0 = 1.0.0). Version indicates minimum engine/language version to run. Language, engine and manifest format versions are tight together into a single version. We assume that all of above are backward compatible or internally can handle differences between versions. Engine internally knows what changed in each version and can use that knowledge to emulate behavior of older versions. UI forms versioning ''''''''''''''''''' UI forms are versioned using Format attribute inside YAML definition. The only way to stay compatible with older format versions is either to support several different formats internally in dashboard or have auto-conversion utility that will upgrade forms on package upload. API versioning '''''''''''''' If single API service can handle several API versions simultaneously it should be done via endpoint prefixes (/v1/, /v2/ etc.). Otherwise there should be several separate services listening on different ports and registered with different names in Keystone. We assume that dashboard-API-engine are always consistent and upgraded as the whole. We also assume to be acceptable for different API versions to have separate databases or tables so that environments created with one version would not be visible to APIs of other versions. API <-> Engine communication versioning ''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''' Because API might require to handle requests from different API versions version number must be added to JSON tasks that API send to the engine. All responses from engine must contain exactly the same version. If engine is to send out of band notifications to the API different versions of API should use different queue names (or any other information that would allow sending notifications to exact recipient) and that information must be provided in original task request. oslo.messaging supports versioning of RPC API, we may employ this here, e.g. have api version = engine rpc version Engine <-> Murano Agent communication versioning '''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''' This topic is addressed by Unified Agent specification Alternatives ------------ Keep strict backward compatibility without ability tp introduce breaking changes. Data model impact ----------------- * Need to store version number for each versioned entity in the database * In many cases uniqueness must be constrained by name and version number rather than by name alone * Requirements for each package need to be stored in database as well REST API impact --------------- None Versioning impact ----------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Deployer impact --------------- All versions of released packages should be available simultaneously. That implies that for core library and other essential packages instead of importing only those packages at system installation all versions of those libraries need to be imported. If there would be several independent API services it would require additional deployment efforts. Developer impact ---------------- Development process need to be changed for correct version tracking. Here is an example how it can be organized: * For each released version of the package there is a separate folder called after version number plus one additional folder called “dev” * During development all changes go to “dev” folder. All packages and requirements have a version “0.0.0” effectively turning versioning off. * After code freeze release manager assign version number to the version about to be released by examining commits happened between releases. It is advised to mark such commits somehow (for example [changes major version], [changes minor version], [changes revision] or something similar). * Requirements may be defined more accurately from the same source * New folder for released version is created and final version of the “dev” package is put there. * Bug/fix and backport commits can be made in between modifying either already released package or making a copy of it with different revision version number according to versioning requirements. * We should write a script to package/upload packages from such versioned folder (e.g. producing a package for each released version) Murano-dashboard / Horizon impact --------------------------------- All uploaded packages fall into 3 categories: * Default package version. That is explicitly marked package version that is used by default when user adds component/application to environment. There can be no more than one such version. If no version was selected to be default the latest version is automatically used for that purpose. * Additional versions. This is all other component versions user is allowed to choose. If user wants to add non-default component version it clicks on a special button/submenu item and selects the version from a list of known versions * Hidden versions. When package is deleted and there is at least one environment alive using it package is not removed but marked as a hidden. Hidden packages are not accessible from dashboard but re-appear if they got re-uploaded. Administrators need to be able to explicitly hide any version of any component. If component is created to fulfill requirements of another component and default version for that component is not version-compatible with requirement dashboard might be smart enough to automatically detect that fact and ask user for a version or use latest compatible version (which is also should be default for the first option) Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Stan Lagun <istalker2> Work Items ---------- * Add support for version numbers and package requirements to manifests and corresponding API/database scheme * Make engine aware of class versions. Allow to have several classes of the same name but different versions is single class loader * Implement version compatibility rules * Improve MuranoPL type resolution rules to include versioning * Design how to implement adapters (may require changes to MuranoPL) Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= In general after each release we should try to old applications on new release to make sure that nothing broke (which may happen if versioning rules were not followed correctly). But it is clear that in practice this cannot be done for all applications in catalog. So we may peek selected set of applications and to try to deploy all versions of those applications on current release. This set should be representative to test the most possible set of futures. Subset of those applications can be used for per-commit tests. Documentation Impact ==================== Changes introduced by each version change of each component should be documented with a guide how to upgrade/migrate existing code. References ========== None

commit_message:
[WIP] Switch to oslo-config-generator

Remove openstack.common.config package.
Remove tools/config folder.
Add etc/oslo-config-generator/cinder.conf
Add cinder.opts module and collect all options from project.

Temporary add the old and new cinder.conf.sample files for comparing.
Implement a script for comparing the old and new configuration files.

Closes-Bug: #1473768
Change-Id: I6e7be74d1a774a6fd1d6d870336cb227a1570144

commit_message:
Enable execute bit on swift sync for directories

Sometimes during sync, directories are created with
644 permissions instead of 755. This mainly impacts
controller reinstallation where resyncing existing
creates inaccessible data files.

Change-Id: I0ad8dfc308324c5a354e13331f0fb6604502b49b
Closes-Bug: #1490960

commit_message:
Rediscover hdisk if connection info refreshed

Although the UDID for a VSCSI attached volume is saved in the bdm
during attach, it can be lost if the connection information is
'refreshed' by the compute manager.  This fix rediscovers the hdisk
during detach if we cannot look it up via the UDID. One scenario
where the connection info is refreshed is live migration.

Change-Id: I13846c494d72d57e47082d4d0fb2a286309aa0f1

commit_message:
Fix RequestSpec.instance_group hydration

A mistake was done by hydrating the members field for the InstanceGroup object when
creating the RequestSpec object because that field is for getting the instances,
not the hosts. In order to provide that information, we need to provide a new
version of the InstanceGroup and give a lazy-load for getting it in case we want to
have it.

Change-Id: I0d892bbe490c9ee727f54077d7398cc2800ce107
Partially-Implements: blueprint request-spec-object

commit_message:
Port the AMQP1 driver to new Pyngus SASL API

Pyngus 2.0 includes a new API for configuring SASL credentials.
Previous versions of Pyngus did not provide this API - the driver had
to invoke Proton APIs in order to configure user credentials.  Moving
to the Pyngus API will preserve compatibility with older versions of
Proton, since the next release of Proton wil be changing its SASL API.

Pyngus 2.0 also adds strict enforcement of callback re-entrancy
constrants.  This patch fixes some bad driver reentrancy violations.

Closes-bug: #1473515
Change-Id: Iddccefd3ee3c9092c086fc54e3810f78d5df9338
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/46/204246/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import shutilimport subprocess import tempfilefrom string import Template@testtools.skipUnless(pyngus and pyngus.VERSION < (2, 0, 0), "pyngus module not present") class TestAuthentication(test_utils.BaseTestCase): """Test user authentication using the old pyngus API"""@testtools.skipUnless(pyngus and pyngus.VERSION >= (2, 0, 0), "pyngus module not present") class TestCyrusAuthentication(test_utils.BaseTestCase): """Test the driver's Cyrus SASL integration""" def setUp(self): """Create a simple SASL configuration. This assumes saslpasswd2 is in the OS path, otherwise the test will be skipped. """ super(TestCyrusAuthentication, self).setUp() # Create a SASL configuration and user database, # add a user 'joe' with password 'secret': self._conf_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp() db = os.path.join(self._conf_dir, 'openstack.sasldb') _t = "echo secret | saslpasswd2 -c -p -f ${db} joe" cmd = Template(_t).substitute(db=db) try: subprocess.call(args=cmd, shell=True) except Exception: shutil.rmtree(self._conf_dir, ignore_errors=True) self._conf_dir = None raise self.SkipTest("Cyrus tool saslpasswd2 not installed") # configure the SASL broker: conf = os.path.join(self._conf_dir, 'openstack.conf') mechs = "DIGEST-MD5 SCRAM-SHA-1 CRAM-MD5 PLAIN" t = Template("""sasldb_path: ${db} mech_list: ${mechs} """) with open(conf, 'w') as f: f.write(t.substitute(db=db, mechs=mechs)) self._broker = FakeBroker(sasl_mechanisms=mechs, user_credentials=["\0joe\0secret"], sasl_config_dir=self._conf_dir, sasl_config_name="openstack") self._broker.start() def tearDown(self): super(TestCyrusAuthentication, self).tearDown() if self._broker: self._broker.stop() if self._conf_dir: shutil.rmtree(self._conf_dir, ignore_errors=True) def test_authentication_ok(self): """Verify that username and password given in TransportHost are accepted by the broker. """ addr = "amqp://joe:secret@%s:%d" % (self._broker.host, self._broker.port) url = oslo_messaging.TransportURL.parse(self.conf, addr) driver = amqp_driver.ProtonDriver(self.conf, url) target = oslo_messaging.Target(topic="test-topic") listener = _ListenerThread(driver.listen(target), 1) rc = driver.send(target, {"context": True}, {"method": "echo"}, wait_for_reply=True) self.assertIsNotNone(rc) listener.join(timeout=30) self.assertFalse(listener.isAlive()) driver.cleanup() def test_authentication_failure(self): """Verify that a bad password given in TransportHost is rejected by the broker. """ addr = "amqp://joe:badpass@%s:%d" % (self._broker.host, self._broker.port) url = oslo_messaging.TransportURL.parse(self.conf, addr) driver = amqp_driver.ProtonDriver(self.conf, url) target = oslo_messaging.Target(topic="test-topic") _ListenerThread(driver.listen(target), 1) self.assertRaises(oslo_messaging.MessagingTimeout, driver.send, target, {"context": True}, {"method": "echo"}, wait_for_reply=True, timeout=2.0) driver.cleanup() sasl_mechanisms, user_credentials, sasl_config_dir, sasl_config_name): properties = {'x-server': True} if self.sasl_mechanisms: properties['x-sasl-mechs'] = self.sasl_mechanisms if "ANONYMOUS" not in self.sasl_mechanisms: properties['x-require-auth'] = True if sasl_config_dir: properties['x-sasl-config-dir'] = sasl_config_dir if sasl_config_name: properties['x-sasl-config-name'] = sasl_config_name self.connection = server.container.create_connection( name, self, properties) self.connection.user_context = self if pyngus.VERSION < (2, 0, 0): # older versions of pyngus don't recognize the sasl # connection properties, so configure them manually: if sasl_mechanisms: self.connection.pn_sasl.mechanisms(sasl_mechanisms) self.connection.pn_sasl.server() # only called if not using Cyrus SASL if 'PLAIN' in self.sasl_mechanisms: user_credentials=None, sasl_config_dir=None, sasl_config_name=None): self._sasl_config_dir = sasl_config_dir self._sasl_config_name = sasl_config_name self._user_credentials, self._sasl_config_dir, self._sasl_config_name)

commit_message:
ironic-agent: ensure dmidecode and ipmitool are installed

Currently they are used for inspection, but may be also used for
other purposes, as they're accessed from IPA generic hardware layer.

Change-Id: I32c6a711d466131b9445023812a2a260ed2e01f3

commit_message:
Set 'heat-admin' as the default user

This patch updates the default firstboot scripts
for TripleO so that we always create a 'heat-admin'
user. This is important because Heat
recently removed the instance_user option which we used to set
the previous 'heat-admin' default user (see
I9d01c5e7de630df5058429353fa17b3536ee8807 or git commit
e423bec7f10b0f5d07f05d195b3b7860f6bceb00 in Heat for details).

Change-Id: Ib20c8375c9fb35e5221fd3aeb0c052c332c66ff3
Related-bug: #1229849

commit_message:
Expose VIF net-id attribute in os-virtual-interfaces

Adds a new microversion to show virtual interface 'net-id' in
virtual interface list.

DocImpact - See nova/api/openstack/rest_api_version_history.rst
for details

APIImpact

Implements blueprint add-vif-net-id-in-vif-list

Change-Id: Ic8b26df8d7e69bd71d23dfbc983fa3449c16fa7d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/72/217572/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 2.12 ---- Exposes VIF ``net-id`` attribute in ``os-virtual-interfaces``. User will be able to get Virtual Interfaces ``net-id`` in Virtual Interfaces list and can determine in which network a Virtual Interface is plugged into.

commit_message:
To use id instead of name when making credentials from context

If tenant_name or user_name has chinese characters,
an 'UnicodeEncodeError' exception raised when making
credentials from request context.
There are two solutions to fix this problem:
1. Call encodeutils.safe_encode to encode the tenant_name
with utf-8 before using.
2. Modify to use tenant_id/user_id instead
of name as other OpenStack projects(Nova, Cinder, Neutron...)
did.

This patch select the  option2 to fix the problem.

Change-Id: I2510405b7b2cc9125828a19a151a56bcd44c2222
Closes-Bug: #1488754

commit_message:
Tokenless authz with X.509 SSL client certificate

Implemented middleware to map an incoming trusted SSL client certificate
into Keystone auth credential so we can perform authorization without
having to issue a token.

TODO: to submit a separate patch to devstack to enable this feature.

Co-authored-by: guang-yee <guang.yee@hp.com>

SecurityImapct
DocImpact
implements bp keystone-tokenless-authz-with-x509-ssl-client-cert

Change-Id: Icc7305ca9d96f8e9cdc95ccde57de650801c6544

added_lines: domain_name = None # if a mapping outputs more than one domain name, log it if domain_name is not None: LOG.warning(_LW('Ignoring domain name %s'), identity_value['user']['domain']) else: domain_name = identity_value['user']['domain'] if domain_name is not None: return {'name': user_name, 'group_ids': list(group_ids), 'domain': domain_name}

commit_message:
Fix import path in neutron-sanity-check for ml2_sriov opts

neutron-sanity-check fails while importing ml2_sriov
configuration. This patch fixes the import path and
also includes a unit test to avoid such issues.

Closes-Bug: #1489374
Change-Id: I4265ee78be9e7f83e35c94187d4577b32005bef9

commit_message:
Allow to use Keystone via 'keystone/api' network

Restrict access to Keystone API from network with
'keystone/api' role, so from outside a cloud it
could be reached only via public VIP.

Change-Id: I6e2004e53591e0cc0b2a5b43a83532d3de9aef9a
Closes-bug: #1489057
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/53/218853/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $keystone_network = '0.0.0.0/0', port => [$keystone_public_port,$keystone_admin_port], proto => 'tcp', action => 'accept', source => "${keystone_network}", destination => "${keystone_network}",

commit_message:
Fixed issue with cacert parameter

We need to use parameter cacert instead of ca_file parameter
to work with CA certificates like python clients for other
OpenStack services.

Also fixed typo (after copy paste from Glance code).

Change-Id: Ibe36390aab2f2edb0fe7670f76f61caeb350d34b
Closes-Bug: #1487099
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-muranoclient refs/changes/48/216148/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'cacert': kwargs.get('cacert'), self.verify_cert = kwargs.get('cacert', get_system_ca_file()) ('cacert', '--cacert %s'),

commit_message:
Revert "Implement asynchronous logger for event callbacks"

This reverts commit e63709d16bd4c1949bef820ac336c9393c040d25.

AsyncLogger's worker thread takes almost 100% CPU because
it infinitely iterates over a logger queue. A simple
"sleep 0.2" will solve this problem, but I have doubts
about that AsyncLogger helps us anyway. It's better to
revert this fix and investigate a real cause of our problems.

Closes-Bug: 1491794
Related-Bug: 1487397

Change-Id: I95d57de9ef92c717b8b07f7832ab258c0b35b6a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/69/220069/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
devstack: resolve image name via image-list, not image-show

python-glanceclient v1.0.0 was recently released and now defaults to
glance api V2.  The client shell for v2 does not offer referencing things
by name and requires we resolve the ID ourselves.  This switches resolving
the id by name and instead pulls it from image-list.

Change-Id: Ib215767f22e5fb8d189e34ea605d1a904d0e7d62
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/astara refs/changes/39/219839/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: typeset image_id=$(glance $auth_args image-list | grep $image_name | get_field 1)
deleted_lines: typeset image_id=$(glance $auth_args image-show $image_name | grep ' id ' | awk '{print $4}')

commit_message:
Fix silently overwrite user specified content type

Previously, even user specified the response content type of api
'catalog/packages/<package_id>/ui', which will be silently replaced
by text/plain. To improve it, add list 'specific_content_types' to
make resource controller can specify different content type for each
action. And it will raise exception when user specified content type
is unsupported.

Change-Id: I5d56461333d730f0f9fbe715e9bb066e5b004203
Closes-Bug: #1476543

commit_message:
Use domain checking for user provider

Enforce domain name checking by using domain_check method.

Note: Implements the following user story:
62-keystone-v3-implement-support-for-default-domain-if-no-domain

Change-Id: I72a7975819c8e51ed118caa0817ea5846c4d2780
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/88/218688/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Liberty: Must warn if no domain is provided and 'default_domain_id' != 'default' # Mitaka: Will warn if no domain is provided even if 'default_domain_id' == 'default' # N+: Will fail if a name is used without a domain unless self.class.domain_check?(resource[:domain]) warning("In Liberty, not providing a domain name (::domain) for a resource name (#{resource[:name]}) is deprecated when the default_domain_id is not 'default' ") end

commit_message:
Expand vSCSI volume connector tests for Dual VIO

This change adds additional test cases into the vSCSI volume connector
to take into account multiple Virtual I/O Servers.

Change-Id: Ie47091f5c818ccfaec716499aca4d992a9c3d9e5

commit_message:
Upgrade the OpenStack environment 6.1 to 7.0

Add chapter to Operations document with description of procedure that upgrades
Mirantis OpenStack environment 6.1 to 7.0 for limited set of Reference
Architecture options.

Change-Id: I9a0df955aa0c2feafcb6e9810144baa5a22491a4
Implements: blueprint upgrade-major-openstack-environment
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/48/214648/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. index:: Upgrade Environment Quick Start .. _Upg_QuickStart: Upgrade Environment Quick Start ------------------------------- .. CAUTION:: Only use this section as a reference. Read the detailed sections below to understand the upgrade scenario before running any of the listed commands. This section lists commands required to upgrade a 6.1 environment to version 7.0 with brief comments. For the detailed description of what each command does and why, see the following sections: * :ref:`Detailed upgrade procedure<upg_sol>` * :ref:`Detailed description of commands<upg_script>` .. CAUTION:: Do not run the following commands unless you understand exactly what you are doing. It can completely destroy your OpenStack environment. Please, read the detailed sections below carefully before you proceed with these commands. Install the Upgrade Script ++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Run the following command on the Fuel Master node to download and install the Upgrade Script in the system: :: yum install -y git git clone -b stable/7.0 https://github.com/Mirantis/octane.git cd octane/octane/bin && ./octane prepare Pick environment to upgrade +++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Run the following command and pick an environment to upgrade from the list: :: fuel2 env list Note the ID of the environment and store it in a variable: :: export ORIG_ID=<ID> Create an Upgrade Seed environment ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Run the following command to create a new environment of version 7.0 and store its ID to a variable: :: SEED_ID=$(./octane upgrade-env $ORIG_ID) Upgrade the first Controller ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Pick one of the Controllers in your environment by ID and remember that ID: :: fuel node list --env ${ORIG_ID} | awk -F\| '$7~/controller/{print($0)}' Use the ID of the Controller to upgrade it with the following command: :: ./octane upgrade-node $SEED_ID isolated <ID> Upgrade State Database ++++++++++++++++++++++ After the first Controller in the 7.0 environment is deployed and ready, run the following command to upgrade the state databases the of OpenStack services: :: ./octane upgrade-db $ORIG_ID $SEED_ID Upgrade Ceph cluster ++++++++++++++++++++ Run the following command to upgrade the Monitor node on the new Controller with the state and configuration of the original Ceph cluster: :: ./octane upgrade-ceph $ORIG_ID $SEED_ID Switch control plane to 7.0 +++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Run the following command to switch the OpenStack environment to the 7.0 control plane: :: ./octane upgrade-cics $ORIG_ID $SEED_ID Upgrade all Controllers +++++++++++++++++++++++ Identify the remaining Controllers in the 6.1 environment by IDs (ID1, ID2, etc): :: fuel node list --env ${ORIG_ID} | awk -F\| '$7~/controller/{print($0)}' Run the following command to upgrade the remaining 6.1 Controllers to version 7.0: :: ./octane upgrade-node $SEED_ID <ID1> <ID2> Upgrade Compute and Ceph OSD nodes ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Repeat the following command for every node in the 6.1 environment identified by ID: :: ./octane upgrade-node $SEED_ID <ID> Clean up the Fuel Master node +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ When no nodes remain in the 6.1 environment, run the following command to restore the original state of the 7.0 Fuel Master node: :: ./octane cleanup-fuel Delete the original 6.1 environment +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ After verification of the upgraded 7.0 environment, delete the original 6.1 environment with the following command: :: fuel env --env $ORIG_ID --delete

commit_message:
Fix docker package name in Ubuntu 14.04 in Install Guide

This patch fixes docker package name in Install Guide.
In case of Ubuntu 14.04, the docker package name is 'docker.io', but
not 'docker'.

Change-Id: If2913cdfe370c511aaa70e8079462f76662cc116
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/94/218694/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: sudo apt-get install docker gzip uuid-runtime cpio findutils grep gpg

commit_message:
Add image signing verification

This patch adds support for the image signing feature by adding the
ability for glance to verify a signature.

This patch still needs:
 * castellan added to global requirements (see Depends-On below)

Depends-On: I2283d2853d4ccd6d41d706db5b02cf6c74c5ba93
Change-Id: I0b0592a3526a4e4f5b39ae6ce8b4dedd0ccc31d9
Implements: blueprint image-signing-and-verification-support

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 The Johns Hopkins University/Applied Physics Laboratory # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Test cases for the barbican key manager. """ import array import binascii import mock from glance.common import exception from glance.keymgr import barbican from glance.keymgr import key as keymgr_key from glance.tests.unit.keymgr import test_key_mgr class BarbicanKeyManagerTestCase(test_key_mgr.KeyManagerTestCase): def _create_key_manager(self): return barbican.BarbicanKeyManager() def setUp(self): super(BarbicanKeyManagerTestCase, self).setUp() # Create fake auth_token self.ctxt = mock.Mock() self.ctxt.auth_token = "fake_token" # Create mock barbican client self._build_mock_barbican() # Create a key_id, secret_ref, pre_hex, and hex to use self.key_id = "d152fa13-2b41-42ca-a934-6c21566c0f40" self.secret_ref = ("http://host:9311/v1/secrets/" + self.key_id) self.pre_hex = "AIDxQp2++uAbKaTVDMXFYIu8PIugJGqkK0JLqkU0rhY=" self.hex = ("0080f1429dbefae01b29a4d50cc5c5608bbc3c8ba0246aa42b424baa4" "534ae16") self.key_mgr._base_url = "http://host:9311/v1" self.addCleanup(self._restore) def _restore(self): if hasattr(self, 'original_key'): keymgr_key.SymmetricKey = self.original_key def _build_mock_barbican(self): self.mock_barbican = mock.MagicMock(name='mock_barbican') # Set commonly used methods self.get = self.mock_barbican.secrets.get self.delete = self.mock_barbican.secrets.delete self.store = self.mock_barbican.secrets.store self.create = self.mock_barbican.secrets.create self.key_mgr._barbican_client = self.mock_barbican def _build_mock_symKey(self): self.mock_symKey = mock.Mock() def fake_sym_key(alg, key): self.mock_symKey.get_encoded.return_value = key self.mock_symKey.get_algorithm.return_value = alg return self.mock_symKey self.original_key = keymgr_key.SymmetricKey keymgr_key.SymmetricKey = fake_sym_key def test_copy_key(self): # Create metadata for original secret original_secret_metadata = mock.Mock() original_secret_metadata.algorithm = mock.sentinel.alg original_secret_metadata.bit_length = mock.sentinel.bit original_secret_metadata.name = mock.sentinel.name original_secret_metadata.expiration = mock.sentinel.expiration original_secret_metadata.mode = mock.sentinel.mode content_types = {'default': 'fake_type'} original_secret_metadata.content_types = content_types original_secret_data = mock.Mock() original_secret_metadata.payload = original_secret_data # Create href for copied secret copied_secret = mock.Mock() copied_secret.store.return_value = 'http://test/uuid' # Set get and create return values self.get.return_value = original_secret_metadata self.create.return_value = copied_secret # Create the mock key self._build_mock_symKey() # Copy the original self.key_mgr.copy_key(self.ctxt, self.key_id) # Assert proper methods were called self.get.assert_called_once_with(self.secret_ref) self.create.assert_called_once_with( mock.sentinel.name, self.mock_symKey.get_encoded(), content_types['default'], 'base64', mock.sentinel.alg, mock.sentinel.bit, mock.sentinel.mode, mock.sentinel.expiration) copied_secret.store.assert_called_once_with() def test_copy_null_context(self): self.key_mgr._barbican_client = None self.assertRaises(exception.Forbidden, self.key_mgr.copy_key, None, self.key_id) def test_create_key(self): # Create order_ref_url and assign return value order_ref_url = ("http://localhost:9311/v1/None/orders/" "4fe939b7-72bc-49aa-bd1e-e979589858af") key_order = mock.Mock() self.mock_barbican.orders.create_key.return_value = key_order key_order.submit.return_value = order_ref_url # Create order and assign return value order = mock.Mock() order.secret_ref = self.secret_ref self.mock_barbican.orders.get.return_value = order # Create the key, get the UUID returned_uuid = self.key_mgr.create_key(self.ctxt) self.mock_barbican.orders.get.assert_called_once_with(order_ref_url) self.assertEqual(returned_uuid, self.key_id) def test_create_null_context(self): self.key_mgr._barbican_client = None self.assertRaises(exception.Forbidden, self.key_mgr.create_key, None) def test_delete_null_context(self): self.key_mgr._barbican_client = None self.assertRaises(exception.Forbidden, self.key_mgr.delete_key, None, self.key_id) def test_delete_key(self): self.key_mgr.delete_key(self.ctxt, self.key_id) self.delete.assert_called_once_with(self.secret_ref) def test_delete_unknown_key(self): self.assertRaises(exception.KeyManagerError, self.key_mgr.delete_key, self.ctxt, None) @mock.patch('base64.b64encode') def test_get_key(self, b64_mock): b64_mock.return_value = self.pre_hex content_type = 'application/octet-stream' key = self.key_mgr.get_key(self.ctxt, self.key_id, content_type) self.get.assert_called_once_with(self.secret_ref) encoded = array.array('B', binascii.unhexlify(self.hex)).tolist() self.assertEqual(key.get_encoded(), encoded) def test_get_null_context(self): self.key_mgr._barbican_client = None self.assertRaises(exception.Forbidden, self.key_mgr.get_key, None, self.key_id) def test_get_unknown_key(self): self.assertRaises(exception.KeyManagerError, self.key_mgr.get_key, self.ctxt, None) def test_store_key_base64(self): # Create Key to store secret_key = array.array('B', [0x01, 0x02, 0xA0, 0xB3]).tolist() _key = keymgr_key.SymmetricKey('AES', secret_key) # Define the return values secret = mock.Mock() self.create.return_value = secret secret.store.return_value = self.secret_ref # Store the Key returned_uuid = self.key_mgr.store_key(self.ctxt, _key, bit_length=32) self.create.assert_called_once_with('Glance Image Key', 'AQKgsw==', 'application/octet-stream', 'base64', 'AES', 32, 'CBC', None) self.assertEqual(returned_uuid, self.key_id) def test_store_key_plaintext(self): # Create the plaintext key secret_key_text = "This is a test text key." _key = keymgr_key.SymmetricKey('AES', secret_key_text) # Store the Key self.key_mgr.store_key(self.ctxt, _key, payload_content_type='text/plain', payload_content_encoding=None) self.create.assert_called_once_with('Glance Image Key', secret_key_text, 'text/plain', None, 'AES', 256, 'CBC', None) self.assertEqual(self.store.call_count, 0) def test_store_null_context(self): self.key_mgr._barbican_client = None self.assertRaises(exception.Forbidden, self.key_mgr.store_key, None, None)

commit_message:
Engine method validate_template fails for unavailable resource type

When validate_template() method is called with unavailable resource type,
it will fails the template validation.

Change-Id: Id141b7e63d7a58fade8a29d0dd5c6a1f9c847f5e
Closes-Bug: #1473025

commit_message:
Use bdm v2 to boot ebs instance for gating

novaclient 2.27.0 has a bug with legacy bdm, and fails on instance boot
attempt. This patch uses bdm v2 instead to workaround the bug.

Change-Id: I3d856b2ba4116c19ab936db63d29413fdfbf31e0

commit_message:
Adding option for Java jobs to be adapted to Oozie

Adding an option for enabling Java jobs to set the
"adapt_for_oozie" flag to automatically modify the job
configs at runtime.  Also adding a unit test that includes
the new option.

Change-Id: Iede36c178aef07912d6f69621d69c1657d1c79b4
Closes-Bug: #1445471

commit_message:
[Sahara] Move node processes selection to own tab

Sahara already have plugin that have huge amout of node processes.
So, sometimes during node group creation it's hard to find some process
from selected service.

So, this patch resolves that issue, because it move node processes selection
to separate tab, and also groups node processes by services.

Implements blueprint: sahara-node-processes-tab
Change-Id: I38cca7e687da1d1c82a5f40cb5846765aa1e43f2

so it is changed to .rst

attempt. This patch uses bdm v2 instead to workaround the bug.

Change-Id: I3d856b2ba4116c19ab936db63d29413fdfbf31e0

commit_message:
Fix gating for DevStack switched to Nova v2.1 by default

Use bdm v2 to boot ebs instance for gating

novaclient 2.27.0 has a bug with legacy bdm, and fails on instance boot
attempt. This patch uses bdm v2 instead to workaround the bug.

Change-Id: I3d856b2ba4116c19ab936db63d29413fdfbf31e0

Use 'compute' service type by default

It was a grand error to use not default service type as a service type
by default. Now DevStack provides v2.1 by 'compute' service type, does
not provide 'computev21' at all. Because that gating fails.

Change-Id: I8a68d331583ea575a5883cd2c451245a9119016b

commit_message:
[RN7-0] OpenStack Kilo support

1. Adds support for OpenStack Kilo
2. Updates the versions of the major components
3. Deletes some unnecessary files from the previous release

Change-Id: If208b3199a1b8dc649727b9e32acc28b7011b237

commit_message:
Remove hardcoded config drive enforcement

This change removes the forced use of config drive to ensure that a user
can choose to use config drive as needed. This adds ability to
disable/enable config drive and allows libvirt to listen for connections
on tcp as needed for live migrations (prohibited otherwise by config drive).

The following new variables were added to nova_common and nova_libvirt
roles, retaining their existing values:

nova_force_config_drive: always
nova_libvirtd_listen_tls: 0
nova_libvirtd_listen_tcp: 1
nova_libvirtd_auth_tcp: none

Conflicts:
  playbooks/roles/os_nova/defaults/main.yml
  playbooks/roles/os_nova/templates/nova.conf.j2

Change-Id: I1de35a4b3611b8bc33a21930dae3fd38f9aaa151
Closes-Bug: #1468514
DocImpact
(cherry picked from commit e65066cf1253c8a27d12c3e3da6797199f0016b5)

   instance is deleted (CVE-2015-3241)
 - Cannot rebuild a VM created from a Cinder volume backed by NetApp
   https://review.openstack.org/203253

This patch removes all SHA specifications for the OpenStack clients
so that any client requirement versions are determined solely from

Tempest requirements are specifically ignored as the tempest role
downloads its required clients directly from pip.

Tempest requirements are specifically ignored as the tempest role

commit_message:
Updated juno to include fix for CVE-2015-3241 - 26 Aug 2015

Updates all repo SHAs to include:
 - [OSSA 2015-015] Nova instance migration process does not stop when
   instance is deleted (CVE-2015-3241)
 - Cannot rebuild a VM created from a Cinder volume backed by NetApp
   https://review.openstack.org/203253

This patch removes all SHA specifications for the OpenStack clients
so that any client requirement versions are determined solely from
the requirements of the OpenStack service and Global requirements
files.

This resolves issues where the client versions we carry are
incompatible with the services, resulting in unexpected failures.

Tempest requirements are specifically ignored as the tempest role
downloads its required clients directly from pip.

Finally, due to the change in the openstack-client version used the
heat domain/role/user tasks fail as they require the CLI to specify
the user and project domain name/id. This patch includes the CLI
changes to ensure that the deployment completes properly.

Change-Id: I88e705d063575f55c32350ead25bc7cc0bcdec08
Closes-Bug: #1489947
Closes-Bug: #1488315
Closes-Bug: #1400881

Closes-Bug: #1487409

Change-Id: I41b3a5a4ba2d48192b505e3720456a77484aa92b
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-21 11:36:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/d9eb0c437da958ae27fb55681fef459387f49431', 'message': 'Fixing haproxy-playbook fails when installing on multiple hosts

Closes-Bug: #1487409

Change-Id: I41b3a5a4ba2d48192b505e3720456a77484aa92b
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-08-22 16:11:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/84b53d777a6895b3155008bafaba24a1ced9dafa', 'message': 'Fixing haproxy-playbook fails when installing on multiple hosts

Closes-Bug: #1487409

Change-Id: I41b3a5a4ba2d48192b505e3720456a77484aa92b
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-08-25 09:19:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/3b889f1cb71bc0c1ad3c6d62dc073bf2adf2a04e', 'message': "Fixing haproxy-playbook fails when installing on multiple hosts

This bug is triggered when haproxy is deployed on multiple hosts
and external_lb_vip is different than the internal one.
As all host receive the same configuration, and are expected
to restart the haproxy service more than once
(once during role and once post_tasks), the playbook will fail,
because the restart of the service fails. The restart of the
service fails on some hosts because haproxy tries to
start/bind to an ip the host doesn't have (avoiding ip conflicts)

This allows haproxy to bind on non_local addresses by
addng a sysctl change in the playbook: net.ipv4.ip_nonlocal_bind = 1
The sysctl is changed for the containers/systems by default.

Side-effect: other services are now able to bind on non-local addresses

This could be overriden by setting the variable haproxy_bind_on_non_local
in your user_* variables. If set to false, then the ip_non_local_bind
sysctl won't be changed.

Closes-Bug: #1487409

Change-Id: I41b3a5a4ba2d48192b505e3720456a77484aa92b
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-08-25 09:36:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/45171d4e4fc20c3139e49d22f90c87ba5c8fdb60', 'message': "[WIP] Fixing haproxy-playbook fails when installing on multiple hosts

This allows haproxy to bind on non_local addresses by

The sysctl is changed for the containers/systems
when external_lb_vip is different than internal address and

Side-effect: other services are able to bind on non-local addresses

This could be overriden by setting the variable haproxy_bind_on_non_local

Closes-Bug: #1487409

"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2015-08-25 10:25:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/238ddb8003286113900a2e91ae7995b53844f4f2', 'message': "Fixing haproxy-playbook fails when installing on multiple hosts

This bug is triggered when haproxy is deployed on multiple hosts
and external_lb_vip is different than the internal one.
As all host receive the same configuration, and are expected
to restart the haproxy service more than once
(once during role and once post_tasks), the playbook will fail,
because the restart of the service fails. The restart of the
service fails on some hosts because haproxy tries to
start/bind to an ip the host doesn't have (avoiding ip conflicts)

This allows haproxy to bind on non_local addresses by
addng a sysctl change in the playbook: net.ipv4.ip_nonlocal_bind = 1
The sysctl is changed for the containers/systems
when external_lb_vip is different than internal address and
the number of haproxy hosts is more than one thanks to a group_var.

Side-effect: other services are able to bind on non-local addresses
if the sysctl is changed.

This could be overriden by setting the variable haproxy_bind_on_non_local
in your user_* variables. If set to false, then the ip_non_local_bind
sysctl won't be changed.

Closes-Bug: #1487409

Change-Id: I41b3a5a4ba2d48192b505e3720456a77484aa92b

service fails on some hosts because haproxy tries to
start/bind to an ip the host doesn't have (avoiding ip conflicts)

This allows haproxy to bind on non_local addresses by
addng a sysctl change in the playbook: net.ipv4.ip_nonlocal_bind = 1
The sysctl is changed for the containers/systems
when external_lb_vip is different than internal address and
the number of haproxy hosts is more than one thanks to a group_var.

Side-effect: other services are able to bind on non-local addresses
if the sysctl is changed.

This could be overriden by setting the variable haproxy_bind_on_non_local
in your user_* variables. If set to false, then the ip_non_local_bind
sysctl won't be changed.

Closes-Bug: #1487409

Change-Id: I41b3a5a4ba2d48192b505e3720456a77484aa92b

commit_message:
Fixing haproxy-playbook fails when installing on multiple hosts

This bug is triggered when haproxy is deployed on multiple hosts
and external_lb_vip is different than the internal one.
As all host receive the same configuration, and are expected
to restart the haproxy service more than once
(once during role and once post_tasks), the playbook will fail,
because the restart of the service fails. The restart of the
service fails on some hosts because haproxy tries to
start/bind to an ip the host doesn't have (avoiding ip conflicts)

This allows haproxy to bind on non_local addresses by
addng a sysctl change in the playbook: net.ipv4.ip_nonlocal_bind = 1
The sysctl is changed for the containers/systems
when external_lb_vip is different than internal address and
the number of haproxy hosts is more than one thanks to a group_var.

Side-effect: other services are able to bind on non-local addresses
if the sysctl is changed.

This could be overriden by setting the variable haproxy_bind_on_non_local
in your user_* variables. If set to false, then the ip_non_local_bind
sysctl won't be changed.

Closes-Bug: #1487409

Change-Id: I41b3a5a4ba2d48192b505e3720456a77484aa92b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/79/215579/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: haproxy_bindable_address_test: "{{ (external_lb_vip_address != internal_lb_vip_address) | ternary('-e '+external_lb_vip_address+'-e '+internal_lb_vip_address,external_lb_vip_address) }}"

Change-Id: Id17c1422e4b1ff350e16f76b6fcaa1ce3aa6f6b4
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-09-02 21:33:15.000000000', 'files': ['jenkins/jobs/rally.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/5912bd4e6d8996a3106b16f525876e1dd7741517', 'message': "Switch Rally gates to new DevStack plugin style

commit_message:
Switch Rally gates to new DevStack plugin style

After this patch was merged: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/190601/
Rally gates become broken.

The check in jenkis/jobs/rally.yaml that should switch to new
plugin style doesn't work (it contains bug).
At this moment we are installing 2 versions of Rally
(with new and old way) one is master another one is master + patch.

As a result Rally gates are testing Rally master instead of
proposed patch to Rally.

This patch removes check of new/old style and use always new plugin style

Change-Id: Id17c1422e4b1ff350e16f76b6fcaa1ce3aa6f6b4

commit_message:
Disable keystone service token

Disable keystone service token in post deployment actions
since that token doesn't represent a user, and carries no
explicit authorization.

Change-Id: I4f2877df1da087f10673edfc855868ebb2245be3
Closes-Bug: #1486015

added_lines: - id: disable_keystone_service_token type: puppet role: [primary-controller, controller, standalone-keystone] requires: [upload_cirros] required_for: [post_deployment_end] parameters: puppet_manifest: /etc/puppet/modules/osnailyfacter/modular/astute/service_token_off.pp puppet_modules: /etc/puppet/modules timeout: 180 cwd: /

subject: Decentralize the managemement of service providers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-15 17:38:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/46fc17e88d0bd9f69ffee9798aa1e8f68c1fa1d9', 'message': 'Allow external services to define their providers

Service plugins may or may not have service providers. Neutron
should have no say into which providers are allowed and which
are not. This should be a responsibility of the service plugin
validation logic itself.

To this aim, this logic is removed from here and moved closer
to where it belongs.

Partial-bug: #1473110

Change-Id: Ia4cad678e6c722ca05821dbdbf05d61523246a86

classes, and attempts to rely less on hardcoded magic.

validation was kept in the neutron core; ultimately this needs to
get closer to the services where it belongs.

This patch starts from ProviderConfiguration and ServiceTypeManager
classes, and aims at removing the hard-coded elements, like the list
of known advanced services, so that in the long run we can make
Neutron easier to plug with external services.

commit_message:
Decentralize the managemement of service providers

After the service split, some of the configuration, parsing and
validation was kept in the neutron core; ultimately this needs to
get closer to the services where it belongs.

This patch starts from ProviderConfiguration and ServiceTypeManager
classes, and aims at removing the hard-coded elements, like the list
of known advanced services, so that in the long run we can make
Neutron easier to plug with external services.

Partial-bug: #1473110

Depends-on: I44edcceba37ac58efcc0a53c9d1f835d9530344a
Depends-on: I8924234aadf786801ffc100d7daa27acc145a195
Change-Id: Ia4cad678e6c722ca05821dbdbf05d61523246a86

commit_message:
Add federated auth for idp specific websso

This commit adds a call the federation API where federated authentication can
be initiated by knowing the identity provider ID, as well as the protocol ID.
This will result in the ability for Identity Provider specific Websso
authentication flows.

Change-Id: Ia84e2fba8337f5f1c1f59986020c7617b367bbc6
Implements: bp federation-idp-websso
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/66/214766/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: FEDERATED_IDP_SPECIFIC_WEBSSO = ('/auth/OS-FEDERATION/websso/' 'identity_providers/{identity_provider}/' 'protocols/{protocol}') _build_federation_rel(resource_name='websso'): { 'href-template': FEDERATED_IDP_SPECIFIC_WEBSSO, 'href-vars': { 'identity_provider': IDP_ID_PARAMETER_RELATION, 'protocol_id': PROTOCOL_ID_PARAM_RELATION, }},

subject: Disable python buffering for gate checks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-29 17:32:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/dc472c8a6a49896ffc2b3feadbfe7b37267fd8dd', 'message': 'Disable python buffering for gate checks

In order to ensure that the ansible output in the jenkins console

commit_message:
Disable python buffering for gate checks

In order to ensure that the ansible output in the jenkins console
log is output as it comes it is necessary to turn off the python
output buffering.

Change-Id: I0f8f11cd04fdfd6c26d5a5afc0e8647648edb1bb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/95/218595/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Disable the python output buffering so that jenkins gets the output properly export PYTHONUNBUFFERED=1

commit_message:
Implement tox.ini config for bashate and pep8 tests

This patch implements tox.ini configuration for bashate and pep8
tests for the purpose of implementing the standard openstack-infra
tests for these.

Change-Id: I72623ea3d531614a803f6b97a9f61f56c376c723
Implements: blueprint gate-split
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/70/216170/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = docs,pep8,bashate# Run hacking/flake8 check for all python files # Ignores the following rules due to how ansible modules work in general # F403 'from ansible.module_utils.basic import *' used; unable to detect undefined names # H303 No wildcard (*) import.deps = flake8 commands = bash -c "grep -Irl \ -e '!/usr/bin/env python' \ -e '!/bin/python' \ -e '!/usr/bin/python' \ --exclude-dir '.*' \ --exclude-dir '*.egg' \ --exclude-fir '*.egg-info' \ --exclude 'tox.ini' \ --exclude '*.sh' \ {toxinidir} | xargs flake8 --verbose --ignore=F403,H303" # Run bashate check for all bash scripts [testenv:bashate] deps = bashate whitelist_externals = bash bash -c "grep -Irl \ -e '!/usr/bin/env bash' \ -e '!/bin/bash' \ -e '!/bin/sh' \ --exclude-dir '.*' \ --exclude-dir '*.egg' \ --exclude-fir '*.egg-info' \ --exclude 'tox.ini' \ {toxinidir} | xargs bashate --verbose"
deleted_lines: envlist = docs,pep8whitelist_externals = bash flake8 {posargs} # Run bash8 during pep8 runs to ensure violations are caught by # the check and gate queues bash -c "find {toxinidir} \ -not -path '*/\.*' \ # stay out of the dot directories -name '*sh' \ # all shell scripts please -print0 | xargs -0 bashate -v -i E003,E011"

subject: Switch Nova/Tempest to use/test Cinder API v2
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-18 07:22:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/bdcfcd8ea75931781cc1a41c7255b852646fa142', 'message': 'Switch tempest to test Cinder API v2

As per https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/deprecate-v1-api
the Cinder API v1 was designated as deprecated in Juno and was meant
to be removed in Kilo, but appears to still be usable in Kilo.

In Liberty gate checks using the Cinder v1 API we are getting
constant failures for the Cinder V1 API tests and related scenario
tests.

This patch turns off Cinder API v1 tests and turns on Cinder API v2
tests instead.

Change-Id: I6513c07e1b5d5653b84ad0b2b490ac8451f2bdf1

to be removed in Kilo, but appears to still be usable in Kilo.

In Liberty gate checks using the Cinder v1 API we are getting
constant failures for the Cinder V1 API tests and related scenario
tests.

This patch turns off Cinder API v1 tests and turns on Cinder API v2
tests instead.

This patch also ensure that nova is using the Cinder v2 API instead
of the v1 API.

commit_message:
Switch Nova/Tempest to use/test Cinder API v2

As per https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/deprecate-v1-api
the Cinder API v1 was designated as deprecated in Juno and was meant
to be removed in Kilo, but appears to still be usable in Kilo.

This patch configures Nova to use the Cinder v2 API instead of the
v1 API.

This patch configures Tempest to test both the Cinder v1 and v2 API's
for now. Once the API is removed upstream we can change this.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1481542
Change-Id: I6513c07e1b5d5653b84ad0b2b490ac8451f2bdf1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/45/214045/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: api_v1 = false api_v2 = true

commit_message:
Ansible register task for MariaDB incorrectly reports failure

When running register task for MariaDB we should firstly check
if operation failed before trying to parse result from json output

Change-Id: Ic331ec20990277d30b147826ff24affb27d52383
Closes-Bug: #1491751

commit_message:
REST API for Murano Dashboard.

This patch adds the start of a horizon rest api module so that
javascript can wrap it. It also provides an AngularJS wrapper.

Change-Id: I53ee3bf1c9d447e0619689e8f649146a6357207b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/15/218515/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. """API for the murano packages service. """ from django.views import generic from openstack_dashboard.api.rest import utils as rest_utils from muranodashboard import api from muranodashboard.api.rest import urls CLIENT_KEYWORDS = {'marker', 'sort_dir', 'paginate'} @urls.register class Packages(generic.View): """API for Murano packages. """ url_regex = r'packages/$' @rest_utils.ajax() def get(self, request): """Get a list of packages. The listing result is an object with property "items". Each item is an image. Example GET: http://localhost/api/glance/images?sort_dir=desc&sort_key=name&name=cirros-0.3.2-x86_64-uec #flake8: noqa The following get parameters may be passed in the GET request: :param paginate: If true will perform pagination based on settings. :param marker: Specifies the namespace of the last-seen package. The typical pattern of limit and marker is to make an initial limited request and then to use the last namespace from the response as the marker parameter in a subsequent limited request. With paginate, limit is automatically set. :param sort_dir: The sort direction ('asc' or 'desc'). Any additional request parameters will be passed through the API as filters. """ filters, kwargs = rest_utils.parse_filters_kwargs(request, CLIENT_KEYWORDS) packages, has_more_data = api.packages.package_list( request, filters=filters, **kwargs) return { 'packages': [p.to_dict() for p in packages], 'has_more_data': has_more_data, }

commit_message:
Allow cinder-backup to use ceph

This change updates ceph_client and os_cinder roles to allow
cinder-backup to use ceph.  We also create a new group called
'cinder_backup' which allows us to only retreive the cinder backup key
if cinder-backup is actually in use.

To use, you would simply need to set cinder_service_backup_driver to
cinder.backup.drivers.ceph in your user_variables.yml file.

NOTE: You will need to update your
      /etc/openstack_deploy/env.d/cinder.yml in order for this change
      to execute successfully.

Change-Id: Ib94effa40208bbc8de0f78c5487316be007adcf1
Closes-Bug: #1481787
Implements: blueprint ceph-block-devices
DocImpact

commit_message:
Implement asynchronous logger for event callbacks

Excludes any lock operations in EventMachine event loop
and its callbacks.

Now in EventMachine callbacks all writings to log are
performed in asynchronous fashion. This way we try to
exclude possibility of blocking and getting deadlock
using classic logging mechanism, which has plenty of
locks internally.

Also similar problem was seen in the next ticket #1453573.

Co-Authored-By: Evgeniy L <eli@mirantis.com>

Closes-Bug: #1487397
Change-Id: I72d0eb01ef8c87e10003338bd3bb70e42a4b7dd6

deleted_lines: Astute.logger.debug("Received cancel notification from in main worker.") Astute.logger.debug "Process message from worker queue: #{payload.inspect}" Astute.logger.debug "Requeue message because worker is busy: #{payload.inspect}" Astute.logger.debug "Process message from service queue: #{payload.inspect}"

Remove requirements.txt for decomposed plugins/drivers

They serve no purpose.

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/core-vendor-decomposition

commit_message:
XenAPI will not inject ssh-key if cloud-init

The XenAPI does not inject an ssh-key if an image
has the "cloud_init_installed" property. Cloud-init
handles key injection.

Closes-bug: 1206943
Change-Id: Iab2ce12b742599491e47a8643c5b83c8e273ad3c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/75/219975/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>If both the XenAPI agent and <package>cloud-init</package> are present in an image, <package>cloud-init</package> handles ssh-key injection. The system assumes <package>cloud-init</package> is present when the image has the <literal>cloud_init_installed </literal> property.</para>

commit_message:
Change get_extensions_path to remove duplicate paths

Split the api_extensions_path in get_extensions_path() so that
duplicated locations in the path can be removed.If not, then it
is possible that the same module is loaded twice due to duplicated
paths, which can cause error.

Closes-bug: #1486861
Change-Id: I7de1e20ab6ff519e51e52b869574931dcf8da797

commit_message:
Prevent ilo drivers powering off active nodes during take over

Currently, ilo drivers powers off active nodes
when a conductor takes over the node from another conductor.
This commit stops this, as active nodes shouldn't be powered
off during take over.

Closes-bug: 1490019
Change-Id: I8e54ae148ed9cfdcb6639a4d089ee82f14de53ba
